comment_text: A video like this could not thrive on TikTok, Instagram Reels, or even Facebook for that matter.  This is my attempt to explain what's good about YouTube, and to encourage decisions within YouTube's leadership to consider leaving a bit of money on the table in favor of protecting the beautiful cathedral that they have created for us.  Following the short-term numbers will destroy the beautiful thing you have created, but if you stay the course and stay true to Your Voice, I believe the fact that Educational content thrives here on YouTube will ultimately make you win in the end.  Thank you to those who work at YouTube for making a platform where beautiful things like this can exist.  The challenge now is to fight to keep it this way, when the siren song of more dollars is no doubt trying to pull you away from that which is good.

It is a product of the purely functionalist approach to things that has seemingly subsumed many aspects of contemporary culture. The term “functionalist” is used somewhat abstractly here. The idea that everything should be optimised for its use within the zeitgeist regardless of any latent or intrinsic meaning or intent either imparted or imbued.
For a building that depends so much on timber and stone to create specific acoustics it'll never be the same.

The asset that YouTube brings is the dissemination of knowledge. Want to see how something is done, do a search on the web and you will likely be steered to a YouTube video. Solder a relay onto a circuit board, there are several programs out there to show how to do it. Build a shed, do some plumbing, repair your car, learn welding, drive a truck. It is also a place to see things from other people's perspective. Hike through the woods, take a motorcycle ride, walk through a city. Learn about how an engineer can take an idea and make it a reality. What are the thought processes, what tools and materials have to be gathered, what are the production and safety factors that have to be addressed? How is success in the project going to be measured? When I see that I begin to understand why some things are done they way they are. The same can be said of news media, politics and government entities. Want to know how your city, county, state or nation works? It's here in spades.

I don't see YouTube as a voice but as the encyclopedia of mankind. It is available to anyone with an internet connection. If that is what it truly is, then this medium should be just that box of knowledge. Interpretation is only for the person who opens the lid to find something. 

Maybe you are re-evaluating your original reasons for creating and publishing content. In my perspective, the vast majority of creators have no expectation of monetization or payments by sponsors. They only wish to pass on information that someone else can use.

I agree that we shouldn't loose our voice, but I don't think that means never changing, notre dame was build 900 years ago, with tools from 900 years ago for people 900 years ago- it's changed a lot since then, the walls would have been covered in tapestry at some times and not others, potentially painted and rendered at certain points. it was pretty extensively damaged in the french revolution (lots of the statues were beheaded and removed) and then restored in the 19th century. The spire we all recognised itself was a recreation in the mid 19th century done in 'the style' of the rest of the cathedral. Some of the glass was damaged in ww2 and replaced with a more modern version- that's not forgetting the history of notre dame, it's memorialising the new history that goes into a building.
Yes changing the building completely wouldn't make sense, but buildings can and should be updated by the people who live in them and use them. History didn't stop x many years ago and in the future people will look at the 21st century renovations in the same way they look at the 20th, 19th ect century ones- part of the building's long and changing history

4:25 this is why I have completely changed course regarding digitization of everything. I used to think its great that you can have your pictures on the cloud and you don't need physical records of stuff because "oh well its all on the computer". But seeing how demanding the internet is and seeing how broad censorship is now... it scares me. A news site can change the wording on an old article and pretend that it was the original publication. A wiki page can be edited to hide less palatable details about a topic or person, or be have modifications locked down to prevent further edits to change a narrative. Google can censor search results it doesn't like. Disney and Warner Bros have been caught splicing out frames from their classic movies or reanimating scenes to make it more "palatable", scrubbing their own history and artistic endeavors to please an increasingly blindly angry mob. Entire books have been canceled by schools; who's to say Amazon hasn't taken controversial books on their Kindle services and have them surreptitiously edited? Google has backdoors to your documents and photos in their cloud services. Facebook and Reddit have backdoors to your posts and private images. It can ALL be edited, with or without your knowledge.

My future home will consist of print copies of my favorite books and classics I have yet to read. No modern reprints, I will scour antique store after antique store to find what I'm looking for. Print and physical media is far superior to digital media. You know its original, you know it can't be edited. A company can't just take it down at a moment's notice. I'm in the process of making photo albums from the pictures I have saved on iCloud. Print is the truest way to archive things.

I think YouTube definitely has its place but it's important to understand that audiences are changing. I love YouTube for the quality content that is available and have found that it has been a great way to connect what we are doing in our school with the PARENTS (and a small amount of students) in our community. My students are leaving YouTube and flocking to other platforms that are quicker, more instantaneous, and 'trendy'. This is a problem but where they are. They aren't on YouTube and I don't know if they are coming back.



Other platforms have a younger audience in general but are more surface level in the learning or void of any positive learning at all (you can see this clearly in some of the ratios between numbers and actual creators and what the content actually is). They want to consume something short, quick, and are not necessarily adverse to learning just maybe not in a 'longform' format (it's crazy what that means to my students as of today). I know my four year old views food the same way but I think it's important that he gets the nutrition he needs to grow. If it means snacking more often, but on stuff that is nutritious and healthy, then maybe I'm okay with that, he's going to end up where he needs to be.



I would love for more educational creators to 'infiltrate' what my students are exposing themselves to on a day to day basis. There is definitely an educational content vacuum in some of these spaces and I think having creators move into this space from time to time is beneficial to help balance what my students are exposing themselves to.

You mentioned that this is a complicated issue and I agree. Here is a point I didn't hear in this video: It may depend on your voice's purpose. I'm not an online content creator, but I was a classroom teacher for 10 years and am now a curriculum writer. If you want to use your voice to educate, for example, it may be in your interest to use these algorithms and different methods to be able to reach more people. You came down on Shorts (and TikTok, etc.) in this video, but if that's how people are consuming media, then I can see a reason for using those spaces to get out a message because that's where it'll be heard. So, I wouldn't come down too hard on creators who adjust things for what they think people might want to hear--at least to some degree--because that's how they'll get heard. Sure, maintain "your voice" but I think there's also a point of going too far with that in which you don't compromise at all and lose your audience. I guess I'm saying that there's a balance needed between being true to your own vision and what needs to be done to accomplish that vision in some cases and that different people will tip the balance at different places.

To be extremely unfair, one of my favorite Youtube features is the "Playback Speed" setting. I listen to almost everything at at least 1.5X, many things at 2X.
The biggest lesson I've learned by doing that is the importance of processing time.
Many persons (such as myself) with no (or little) useful site use computers with screen readers, and some of us push the words-per-minute well past 5- or 600. The ingestion of the information is rarely a problem; processing it and making it personally relevant is the tough part.
I think the most difficult part of watching Youtube, the biggest thing that loses voices (either personally or socially) is jumping from post to post, video to video, without giving oneself processing time.
That's why I turn off "Autoplay." I want to choose what and when to watch next.
That's why, if I were a creator, I would post videos when I had something to talk about: maybe four a week, maybe one a month, without letting myself become an assembly line of content. No accusation at all is intended in that; I don't really know your upload schedule, but we all need time to think, discover, and discuss.
Be well, and thanks for the videos.

this video can be criticized by looking at it from the other end:
you're fighting to not lose your voice.... but did it ever occur to you that there's people who don't even want to listen?
that fact is one that the algorithm also works with: it will never recommend your video to people who don't even speak your language.
because, if that people was remotely interested in speaking your language, they would have their front page set to your language and not theirs.
......therefore, youtube assumes you don't even interest them.

language, theme, length of video, color palette, .... you name the parameter.
I get recommended videos I'm not interested in, because I have disabled cookies and tracking, and I have rejected any analysis of my behavior.
so, what does youtube do? it recommends me things that people around me usually look for.
it aims for "relation by proxy"... "you're Italian! surely you must like pizza!", or "you're German! surely you must love beer!"

doesn't matter how popular your channel is, .... it is unpopular by default if you're still unknown to those people who would definitely benefit from the content you're uploading.

Just keep thinking that money is not the most important.

is it me, or do the statues look different on the Arch du Triumph (is that how you spell it?) comparing the two they look like different reliefs.
edit. i went to google if it was ever replaced and found i spelt it wrong 'Arc de triomphe' my bad. Anyway, i found out someone flew a biplane under it and it was caught on newsreel in 1919!!
Anyway, the relief on the right on the old photo looks like an angel above a guy falling off a horse with another guy standing in the bottom with two people kneeling either side of him and holding onto him. which is not what is there in the modern one, which is Le Marseillaise. the one in the black and white old pic is actually La Paix de 1814. which just means he took the modern pic the wrong side of the Arc and took a pic of the reverse side to what was took in the old pic. So in the side by side what we're really seeing is both sides of the Arch at different ties, not the same side. which is still cool.
If i hadn't looked this up, i would have honestly thought we had a genuine pic of the arc from an alternate dimension.. thankfully Wikipedia exists.

Interesting, and more nuanced than I expected. Good stuff. I wanted to comment on Notre Dame de Paris and its restoration. The man primarily responsible for the past restoration of this cathedral, and many others, was Viollet Leduc, who worked around the time of Napoleon, but lived long enough to influence the early Chicago skyscraper architects.

This influence arose from his appreciation of the capabilities of cast iron, the carbon fibre of his age. He realized that the form of the Medieval cathedral – what we call the Gothic – was in many ways as pure an expression of engineering logic as could be achieved in their era. Without calculus and infinitesimal mathematics, those architects/masons/designers were trying to pull the most out of material available. When Viollet Leduc recreated the spire that fell so spectacularly in the fire, he used (I believe) cast iron to do so, something that wouldn't have been possible for the original buliders. The original had been removed because it couldn't stand up to the wind loads.

So, it was natural that Louis Sullivan would be influenced by him. And, I would argue, it puts Notre Dame in an engineering continuum, where the continuous duty of care is to respect the original construction, but also to consider what the underlying motivations were – to express the aspiration of the human spirit through the medium of engineering and technology. 

Another architect who was massively influenced by Viollet Leduc was Gaudi, who, when he inherited Sagrada Familia, it was a traditional neogothic cathedral of the type that Viollet LeDuc had defined. Saudi's transformation of the Sagrada Familia into the extraordinary structure – and I'm sure that you know about the incredibly inventive use of suspended chains that were used as a kind of early CAD that anticipates what Gehry and others have used to liberate building structure – set the tone for a building that is continuously being reinvented as an engineering invention of staggeringly comprehensive scope.

Change is good. The preservation of things is never the truth, as your Audio Traveller project shows. It's the life, and that is what the architecture – and the engineering – should serve....

3:50 As someone who lives in a 1500y old city, and as an architect myself, I can say we have a very different perspective on this for most historical buildings. Because we have to...
Thing is our cities are so old that if we didn't renovate and update them, they'd simply die. Although I do agree that a monument like the Notre dame should be kept as original and intact as possible, this just isn't possible or plausible or viable for many other buildings. There's just too many. If we kept and maintained every historical building in its original form, our cities would turn into dead museums full of empty, lifeless, well preserved shells.

Old buildings need to be renovated to give them new life, so they can be used and maintained for another 1000y. These buildings often were built to last, but they were also built to be used. So it makes sense to keep them as intact as possible, but to also update them, keep them in use, and keep them alive for generations to come.

Great example of this can even be found with monuments, like for example the Louvre in Parijs. It was updated/upgraded to handle more tourists and visitors, to keep the museum alive, but also to maintain it as it is by adding another modern entrance. And this is the now famous glass pyramid of the Louvre. The Louvre had been there for centuries. Many protested the construction of the pyramid. But it allowed the Louvre to continue into the 21st century, and it has become so iconic and so part of the Louvre now, now no-one can even imagine the Louvre without it anymore.

And thing is, this had been done for centuries. For example many buildings have a Mish mash of styles because over the centuries things were added, renovated, and so on. This is as old a practice as architecture is. In my own city we have a city hall partially built in gothic style and partially built in renaissance. Because by the time they got to that renaissance wing, the style and fashion had changed. The cathedral is gothic, but it's interior is baroque because it was refurbished during the contra-reformation. There's a gothic style guild building with a 90s glass addition built right into it, and now it's modern office space. And so on, and so on. If notre dame had burnt down 200-300y ago, they would most probably have reconstructed it with a new "modern" baroque or classisist roof, or even would have completely renovated or rebuilt it in these new, then "modern" styles.

Even if some changes are made to Notre dame, it will probably be done with lots of respect and care, and it too will probably allow the cathedral to survive another couple of centuries. That's just how it goes.

Not to be pedantic ... hides "I'm a pedant" hat, shreds "Professional Pedant" business cards ... but can you break down/delve into what you mean by Voice? I get part of it, but I see some things stated explicitly and implicitly that I have questions about.

Don't we all change with every choice we make? How much energy should we put into keeping something/someone/ourselves from changing? Doesn't the French government have a long-standing penchant (and has enshrined into law) for making sure most aspects of French culture do not change—and how does that impact visitors, emigrants, and refugees? What does 1/24th of a second of a captured moment convey and what do we owe it? Doesn't Wikipedia hold onto the history of a page and all its changes? How does Voice inform/impact Goals? Can ones Voice stay one's own while Goals change?

Curiosity questions, not judgmental ones.

Agreed that YouTube shouldn't lose their "voice" (though arguably that has already happened on a few occasions - think of the changes content creators had to adapt to after the so-called adpocalypse, for example).
That said, there's an argument to be made for extending your voice as well. Its equally bad for YouTube, content creators and content consumers if the platform cannot remain competitive. That puts YouTube in a particularly interesting position: Things like "shorts" can help attract (or at least retain) viewers from sites like TikTok, while at the same time because YouTube also has the long-form content available, they could, if they chose to set their algorithm up correctly, be in a position to slowly nudge people towards videos that are more informative - or at the very least towards videos that don't train us to have the attention span of a gnat.

The Notre Dame repair may not be a good example of losing one's voice; Gothic architecture was specifically designed for contemporary pilgrimage. Gothic cathedrals contained ambulatories and reliquaries to allow pilgrims to walk around the church even during a service.

So it's a real question whether modern tourist features or the contemporary pilgrimage features from the hundreds of years of Notre Dame's construction are more in the original spirit.

If the world changes, and the conversation changes, are the forms of the original context more important than being understood in the new context? As gorgeous a a building as Notre Dame is, what makes its original context more privileged than the new context?

hey Destin, that introduction is very deep! you should resist creating short clips if it don't add any value to your content (voice). in fact, sometimes I find it derogatory. for example, there is a channel I subscribed a few months ago through a short clip and hoped for more interesting videos, but found out this channel ultimately is producing short clips that don't have the same entertainment impact.

Thinking about it (LOL), most if not all of the things I've really appreciated on youtube have been extended analysis of a thing. There are definitely channels that lean into this far too much and always make a 25 minute video about a 10 minute subject (e.g gaming news), but the absolute best stuff is all in that 30-50 minute zone (and to be honest, the time just races by because the content is so good.)

I don't necessarily agree that short videos aren't thought provoking or educational, in fact there's some profoundly smart tiktoks that take a very complicated subject and thearterise it in such a way that you suddenly have an insight into the topic that you didn't before, and, now that you have that insight, you actually have a chance of getting to grips with it. But that's definitely a very different type of way of being clever.

(Also, it's just really really easy to spot padding and/or someone dragging something out to hit a certain schedule. Commercial TV used to do it all the time, carefully packaging about a minute of actual content in a half-hour show. So you might be tempted to lean into the algorithm, but if by doing that you end up boring your audience, that's still going to affect the long term health of your channel.

A very interesting point of view and I took notice of your remarks about Notre Dame and the plans to "update" things to appeal to a modern audience. While I understand your point of view about avoiding change to satisfy your audience, to some extent, this is what every public-facing business needs to do. And make no mistake, The Church is a public-facing business. They need to adapt to the times in order to maintain their membership. The splintering of the Christian religion, I think, is evidence of what happens when you don't keep up with public sentiment. The "we're right, you're wrong, we know what we're doing" attitude is the death knell of any business.

I think you, as a content creator, are fully entitled to create your content in any way you see fit. I think it's good on you to "stick to your guns" and not let yourself be corrupted by the desire to appease others. If your goal is to satisfy yourself with this content, then by all means stay true to yourself. On the other hand, if your goal is to make a living I think you will find yourself needing to adjust your content to keep up with the times.

I’m from the Orkut generation and don’t use Facebook & Instagram anymore. It’s been 1.7 years now and my mind feels a lot more clear now, I don’t get irritated easily or feel low anymore. So, my advice would be to not just resist but decide that you won’t do shorts until unless social media gets fixed.

I think "loosing your voice" also largely depends on what your end goal is.  If your end goal is to "curate your life" it makes sense to not loose your voice, however, if your end goal is to instead "promote a product or idea" I think loosing your voice is a means to an end.  Its the difference between doing a project for your own edification vs being contracted to do it for some other reason.  There are merits and drawbacks to both.

Stellar video with a message that really resonated with me. I tend to be a convergent communicator and pose myself as more like others to blend in. But while some degree of that is adaptive, I don't want to just be a copycat either. I also find myself at times trapped in content consumption that ends up taking away time from other things I do enjoy, like crafting or reading or gardening - things that give me more meaning than the content I'm scrolling through online. it's a tricky balance, especially when people want short and fast. But as you can tell by the length of my comment, I do like to spend more time with something (which means I tend to take a while to get things done, but that's another story).

Side note - as a hobbyist photographer, I've noticed that I've gone from wanting people-free videos (yeah, I was more of a misanthrope back then) to having that mix where I like capturing landscapes or objects, but also human moments. Things that aren't posed or planned that represent an unrepeatable moment. And I think that connects with the idea of not losing your voice, and the idea of passing time, because it's not a cookie cutter insta shot designed to be aesthetic, but the aesthetic appeal comes from an intrinsic feature of the moment that will never be again.

Finally, as a viewer, I do like the long format, I do like the depth and thought, even though I can't always feed the algorithm about this. Don't lose your voice, Destin!

Fascinating seeing the past and present of the same locations.

I was living in Germany when the pyramid was added to the courtyard of the Louvre and the entrance was changed from the original one on the street. I got to go to the Louvre before the change, to see the controversy over the plans, and the the utterly amazing results. Since I am a history buff, I was firmly on the side of the "this modern addition won't possibly fit". After the pyramid was done, I was and am firmly on the side of it being an amazing and oddly fitting addition to the museum/palace. I have a hard time imagining/remembering what it was like before. I see pictures, I know I was there before, I know I entered from the street and not the courtyard, but the pyramid and new entrance are so.. fitting they override my memory somewhat. And one of the side benefits of putting in the pyramid and courtyard entrance was uncovering walls from the original palace built by Philipe August in the 12th century.

I am glad I also got to see Notre Dame then, too, and was/am devastated to see the effects from the fire. I am very hopeful for the reconstruction.

But, in the realm of reconstruction, cleaning, etc. When they cleaned the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, there was a great controversy. They were cleaning away not only the pollution of modern times but also other efforts of cleaning, restoration, and preservation (some of which caused degradation). There was great outrage over the brightness of colour being revealed, but it was/is no brighter or vibrant than the colours in the illuminated books which preserved their colours by being shut and not exposed to light. In the end, again, the restoration changes now seem to be normal even to the eyes of the most critical.

I know this is now 6 days old but still, as a content creator and watcher, I find some patterns happening on YouTube and that is, one, I think I agree that YT is still struggling to find itself, and along the way, loosing it's original intent. I also find many creators doing exactly as you say, loosing their voice by one, allowing too many influences to influence their channel, that is, trying to make it perfect, hiding mistakes and cutting out (often crudely) flubs etc, and that becomes annoying when it's multiple jump cuts in a row.

Too many creators are also "influencers", what exactly does that mean? I sometimes wonder if some creators are taking that too literally and perhaps a bit too far. Also, many may be finding that trying to cram too many subjects into a 10 minute video regardless whether it should be longer or not and I find that tiresome and rather frenetic, and others don't even bother to edit, much if at all, and thus lots of shots from afar that drone on for minutes before the move the camera in closer. My videos are varied in that they can be as short as 10 minutes or up to an hour or a bit more and on average I run roughly 30 minutes long now. I also edit, but when I need to jump forward, I often will utilize a cross dissolve, to lessen the jerkiness of jump cuts. I also find too many creators are struggling to find their voice, by trying to copy others, thus too many similar content from many channels. Some stand out from the sea of similar channels by being original in their presentation and how they go about it, others come off as too me too! Part of why I don't just subscribe wantonly to just any channel, usually.

But finding that voice means, be yourself, don't try to be something you are not is key here to how some channels are successful, or not, and it's not all that easy to find that voice, so some "throw it at the wall and see what sticks" is necessary at the beginning, but I find if you just be you, the likely you'll succeed.

BTW, the shortest video was shot in Oct, and was just over 2 minutes, 2 minutes and 15 seconds and it was a gorgeous sunrise one morning, then the next day, it was foggy. Showed that, and it's just a regular upload, no official shorts clip, but I find that on occasion, it can be not a bad thing if the subject warrants it, otherwise, I don't do click baits or any of that, as one, I find too many people dislike the click bait tactic, especially when it is treated as such. I recall all that when it was announced a couple of years ago and my reaction was, WTF?

My Great Grandfather was a very smart man. Born in the late 1800's in Arkansas, he took photographs on huge 8x10 glass plates that he actually made his self with chemicals. He never used ISO's or F-stops, he just took the cap off and got used to how long he needed to expose them. Such clarity and unbelievable detail. When I look at a photograph, I see the meaning of Spacetime. For those not familiar with Spacetime it is the space and the time you or something happens in that space and time. In short you are alive, you fill a particular space at a particular time. Photo's show us those people, things and events that happened in that spacetime. Before photographs, we had to rely on word of mouth or written documents coupled with whatever physical evidence that was left to determine what actually happened and it can often be wrong.
There is a lot more to it all. But you and I occupy a spacetime, no one else does and no one else can. That is why there will never be time travel like in the science fiction films. What happened before us, is gone. What happens after us, we will never know. But those that come after us, might be able to see a tiny spot of our spacetime, through photos and videos, but will never really know what it was like for us.
Spacetime is really a very deep and interesting subject to study.

What an amazing thing you guys have done with that capture of what Notre Dame looked and sounded and felt like on that one particular day. I studied history at the undergrad level, mostly focussing on Canada's history and 20th century Britain with an emphasis on wartime and the inter-war period. My professors really pushed us to seek those types of sources alongside the scholarly books and essays we would read. We watched the films people were watching at the time. We read fiction novels published at the time. We got assigned a month in time and spent a semester studying all of the preserved films of full runs of newspapers. Not just the front page articles but the classifieds and the editorials. You truly cannot study a period in history and get anything close to the full picture without finding a way to experience what the people living then and there experienced.

Things like the footage you guys created of being a tourist in Notre Dame will be that sort of invaluable resource in the future. This isn't just photographs and blueprints and maybe a carefully recorded sermon by that priest, it's how the crowd reacted, it's what the crowd was wearing, it's the other conversations you'll overhear snippets of as people pass each other.
Feels like TikTok has become for daily quick updates and yt has become for large big productions.

This, the fascination of conserving information in physical objects, is why I like Vinyl records, and plate negatives.
I am working at electron microscopes, and CMOS cameras are fine, but my favourite medium still are 6,5x9cm plate negatives. The field of view and amount of detail you can capture at medium magnifications would require several images at much higher magnification (burning the sample much faster).
And if you look at them through a stereomicroscope, you can see the grains of silver suspended in gelatin that form the actual image, that´s just super fascinating. Plus, if you treat them correctly, they are virtually for eternity. And you have no compatibility issues as long as you have any light source....

Your voice is not in a vacuum. If you are saying something and the person you are talking to walks off and somebody else turns up it would be sheer lunacy to keep saying the same thing.

So the world changes around you, both in the media it gives you for communication and the audiences it gives you and it’s no good to just keep doing the same thing because it’s your thing. That’s not to say that you should change to what an audience or an algorithm wants but it absolutely means that you should be taking those into account and adapting your output appropriately.

There’s a parallel to be made with code switching when talking to people of different backgrounds. You will speak differently to your family than you would to a wide audience or to business people you’re pitching to. You have different reference points in common and different purposes to your communication. And, yes, there is a bad part of it where your voice mighty not be appreciated by certain sectors and you have to make a decision as to whether that’s reasonable or whether you should be doing something to educate your audience.

I respect the idea of trying to be resistant to change due to outside stimuli, but to me it feels like fighting an uphill battle.  I get that this video is specifically talking about youtube, and resisting change due specifically to the algorithm, but we're social animals.  Everything we do gets positive or negative feedback, which then impacts whether or not we'll do something similar in the future.  It's romantic to think that we have an unchanging "voice" that defines each one of us, but that's just not true.  Every time we interact with the outside world, we're being conditioned one way or another.  In short, we're all Pavlov's dog, and while I won't pretend to know which level of resistance to conditioning is appropriate, and the answer is certainly not none, but it also is not as much as possible.
If the message takes time to convey, then take that time. As long as the audience is kept interested in receiving the message because it's on-topic, they'll stay.

I got to visit the UK in 2017 and we toured the St Paul's Cathedral. We had an elderly gentleman escorting us around, when we got to the back of the Cathedral he stopped and said it had been destroyed by a German bomb and when rebuilt, it was dedicated to all the US Airmen who died defending the UK. He asked if anyone had relatives who died during that time and I was the only one who raised his hand. The gentleman straightened up, came over and shook my hand and thanked me!! He showed me the book encased in glass which had all the names of the US servicemen who died defending the UK. When we had finished the tour, he took us over to 2 large books that also had the names in them and we searched for my mothers first cousin who captained a B-17 and perished on his 2nd mission, he even allowed me to photograph it for my mother!! When we returned to our flat for the night, I called mom and she was in tears saying, "they didn't forget him, they didn't forget him..."!!! That's the "Human" part of these old, broken down, hard to heat buildings that shouldn't be touched in my humble opinion!! They remind us of where we came from, and where we'll go again if we forget where we came from!!! God Bless You Destin, and thanks!!! :-)

I've been considering making YouTube videos for a while now, and the biggest thing that gets in the way has been my concern with trying to please the algorithm. I've kind of kept an eye on what YouTube expects in terms of the algorithm, and at no time has it ever been very favorable for any kind of content I want to create. I can't do a video every day, and I'm honestly not sure I could even keep up with a video a week, so the whole frequent new videos thing doesn't work for me. The timing expectations are all over the place, with the algorithm typically preferring video lengths in exactly the wrong place for me. I also doesn't help that some of my topics are fairly niche, so it's not like I could ever get enough views/subscribers to expect to get paid. And the fact is, I'm unwilling to try to fit myself to YouTube's expectations. The kind of content I would produce just doesn't fit YouTube's expectations, and if I tried to make it fit, quality would suffer.

Sometimes keeping your voice is just deciding where you are willing to speak. I do hope I can eventually make YouTube videos (there are other things preventing me right now), but when I do, it is going to be on my own terms. I might be able to get some support for it through things like Patreon or donations in BAT. If that doesn't work out, maybe I'll have to wait till I am old and retired to do much. The fact though is, I know I don't have to give in to the pressure, and recognizing that you have a choice is the first step in choosing and being who you want to be.

Anyhow, thanks for all of your videos, and I hope you have continued success here, not just for you, but also for myself and everyone else you are benefitting.

I like thought provoking videos, so thank you for this one. Thinking for a moment or two about the main metaphor (chasing views & rebuilding a landmark) I found myself agreeing with one and disagreeing with the other. That’s odd for metaphors: am I not getting it or is it a poor metaphor?
So I ‘reversed engineered’ the destruction of a cathedral and what that would be like for a YouTube creator. Maybe it is more akin to a glitch destroying your content. You have the footage to recreate old videos exactly the same or change them. Having watched you a lot, I feel like you would think about what the video tried to communicate and then see if changes to the original could do a better job than that, given years of experience.
Notre Dame, like many historical sites, don’t have a function (like a platform), but like the photos you collect, I think of them as a object onto which we project meaning. We didn’t meticulously preserve a rebuild the hovels of the labourers that built the cathedral, and there are churches in Europe that are being converted to apartments or night clubs. Objects are not like the Notre Dame in your old photo, but the photo: it’s meaning and purpose changes.
But the pressure platforms create on creators by showing data is different and I agree with you so much… I would to see research in Instagram or TikTok, looking at long term changes in content correlated with likes of prior content. I think people often drift towards what gets likes, make more of that and push it further. From all the issues you point out, it feels like the risk is not to lose yourself fully, but to become a caricature of yourself. A version that loses nuance and complexity, the human element, by exaggerating the few things people give you attention/views/likes for.
(I also sometimes want platforms where there is a minimum word count for comments, for obvious reasons).

And there I was thinking this video was going to be about the unnecessary removal of the dislike button on publicly-available YouTube videos. This is much deeper than that. I appreciate you raising this issue. Never change!

I don't know if this is necessarily related but I had a girlfriend when I was much younger (in college) and she was obsessed with photoshopping her images that she would post to Myspace (yeah, I said it, her MYSPACE). I never really said anything to her about it because I wanted her to do whatever it was she felt she needed.
Fast forward to many years later when we have both lead our separate lives for quite a while, whenever I decide to take that trip down memory lane and I'm looking at photos of her that I have saved, none of them are her curated, and photoshopped, images. They are all the candid photos that we took together where she looks exactly the way that I remember her.
It kind of makes me sad to think that kids today, who no doubt curate and photoshop/edit everything before posting to social media, will never have an actual record of how things were.
Before I sound too old and crotchety, I understand that makeup and photo-trickery has been a thing for decades before modern digital technology existed, but my point is that everyday, and mundane, photos are now being manipulated as well, so there will be no future record of how people actually looked.
Maybe this isn't going to be a real problem but for me, personally, I'm very glad I have photos of my college girlfriend, and ALL of my college friends for that matter, who look exactly as they looked the day the photos were taken.

I've been subscribed to the OG learning channels like you Veritasium and Vsauce solely because I literally want to just learn. The thing is, your channel satiates the kind of thirst that the audience have which is to be engrossed into things that don't necessarily involve in our everyday lives, but is interesting enough that it provides a different perspective on effective things for us to use that we take for granted. I never cared for how carburetors work. But because you and your dad were passionate about your lawn mower, I learned how intricate the science is to have any motor work, especially on vehicles albeit not the same but very similar. I know what it does to my car when I punch the gas a little too hard and I'm more cautious about that now. I now have a new found appreciation on how much preparation, time, and hard work it took for people who invented and made things that resulted in very effective machines that we don't even worry about them until they break down.

I think platforms and creators that always championed the innate desire that people want to learn anything and everything around them has taken the latter for granted. As much as we like to turn off our brains once in a while and have a laugh on Tiktok, we also are, evidently since your channel is going strong, craving for things that are more profound. Youtube punishes creators for making videos shorter than 10 minutes but are also pressuring them to make "shorts" is sending some mixed signals. I've always appreciated your content and am always excited with every new upload you put out on your channel. Thank you for all the years you've spent making learning interesting.

Just a note on Catholic churches. They change over time and the European ones  change as they are built. For instance some start being built in a Romanesque style heavy with rounded arches then proceed though the gothic styles and get more ornate at the top. If I remember correctly Chartres cathedral is like this, or they burned/fall/torn down and replaced partly or totally in a different style ie. St. Peter's in Rome. Another is liturgical when the counsel of Trent came about the Priest turned facing the altar and the altar was pushed against a wall. Then Vatican 2 came and changed it. I think also there was a time that it was more like the Orthodox and the sanitary was completely enclosed. Just a minor thing that buildings can have a life of their own.

I on YT watch about 1/2 educational and 1/2 entertainment content. But all of it essentially is over 10min and usually up to hours. I did switch for a while to YouTube shorts, and other competitors because everyone else did. I went 1 week just to see how it goes. I found that I liked it a lot and I went for another month and after that month as I was watching a short I looked at the time and realized 2 hours passed. I immediately said "ok cool what did I watch in two hours" It then occurred I could not remember a SINGLE video even the one I just stopped watching.  Right then and there I quit Shorts, I noticed they 100% have a negative impact on my life, those hours were wasted, if you can't remember what occurred, then you wasted your life. While here, the memories of the oxygen candles on subs is still in my head. This is because I found that fascinating and ever since I have thought of that in fascination, for you it might be slow-mo sprinkles hit with a baseball, or the way Pecans are harvested, maybe it is the effects of bullets underwater or prince Rubert drop strength. ALL of these are videos where I know I gained an appreciable amount of knowledge and entertainment to have stuck with me for years.   That is this channel and Destin will agree with me, there is some other amazing content on this platform. People are smart and we can learn a lot from them, and that is fun.

"Don't lose your voice" is advice that I find all but impossible not to follow.

It's not that it is impossible to be influenced by others and outside pressures, but it's that how you are influenced is a process that happens within oneself. Your resistance to the pressure of playing into the youtube algorithm is a part of your voice, just as somebody changing their content to better conform is a part of their voice.

I think that what one should really be careful of is being deaf to their own voice. As while everything one says and does is in their voice, not understanding or knowing their own voice can be extremely difficult to handle.

Truly, having a crisis of identity is not a fun time. Trust my words as somebody whose been there and back a few times.

And to anyone reading this who is there now: know that even if you don't see an answer, that in itself is part of the answer. As the answer is, and always will be, you. Even if you can't fully grasp all that the answer entails, that's okay; I'm almost positive nobody does or can fully understand their own answer.

I understand not wanting to lose your voice, but I don't think the argument of resisting change is very applicable in this situation.. In the instance of the Notre-Dame cathedral, I'm not religious and don't feel like I have any right to talk about how, while preserving it's history is important, change is equally important to help newer generations gain interest or those who have seen it before to go back. If you love something, you want others to be interested in it too, right?
As for Shorts, I don't think resisting it is a good idea either, and I don't think you "lose" your voice by doing so. Shorts isn't necessarily about making new content cut down to be more consumable, it's about discoverability. By taking certain clips (funny or interesting) from your current videos, you can re-use content that attracts more people to the rest of your channel or to watch the full length video. Shorts are more like good Thumbnails or Titles, they get people interested in checking out the content. Just something to consider if anyone ever sees this.

Please everybody, keep the detail. I don’t tune in here to hero worship, I tune in to learn how to make things, create art and navigate the minutia in a given project. I tune in here to learn the little stuff and the big stuff, and flashy music, better sound and better lighting doesn’t necessarily mean a better lesson.

The nuance I see here is, while using this platform to share/keep/pass-down human experience/memories is definitely a worthy thing to fight for, it is a different thing when it is your source of income, and/or job in a free marketplace where apart from slight nudges like this, there is no requirement to follow the "algorithm". Especially if your main priority is to keep memories. If you want to have your cake and eat it too, then one of these priorities will have to compromise in order to make it work. As in, if you want to earn income on this platform and make your own videos with your own way, maybe one doesn't need to care about what the algorithm does to your viewership. If on the other hand, this channel is a main source of income, "pleasing the algorithm" that gives you the platform might be the way forward, until another platform comes along and changes the way viewership and rewards are architected. At that point there is real competition to high value educational videos like your excellent channel has.

Of course, some folks have been turned off of long-form content by pompous windbaggery and presenters padding things out rather than digging into them. Ultimately, as you noted, the nature and honesty of the content has to be how we judge the quality of the content.

Your brain will produce ideas and thoughts of the same quality as the data you feed it. 'Attention span' is a muscle not a trait (although, like all muscles, some will be more or less nourished). i'm pausing this video 4 minutes in to address your point on the cathedral (i'll edit or delete if you come back to it in a relevant way later on) :
i have no doubt that the cathedral, when it was built, was built to accomodate the people who would come visit and 'use' it. There's a point in architecture where you have to ask yourself "what is this built for". It actually takes place in the real world and, more often than not, in places that meet geographical limits so a certain level of 'efficiency' or at least 'purpose' has to be considered.
A church burning down is a catastrophe but it's also an opportunity to ask those questions again. Notre dame burned down in 2019 -- that's now part of its history -- what can we do to add to its history and purpose rather than attempt to crystallize it ? After all, as you said, it's been an evolving work of achitecture for centuries, even after it was 'done'

5:12 What I like about slides is the fact that the light from the object caused a chemical reaction in the emulsion which was then developed. But unlike photographs or digital photography, the slide has the original chemicals with the captured energy of the photons of light from the object. The negatives of regular photographs are the same, but those are not what we view. It is almost like capturing a little piece of the object as it was the moment the photograph was taken.

By the way, I still have my father's old Argus slide projector and several boxes of slides in those same long racks, like the one you are holding.

Seriously, though, one of the things I've come to love about your videos is that you explain, in easily relatable terms, how things work. It's obvious that your engineering background drives you to look at things in that way, but what really clinches the views for me is your ability to make things clear.

That said, there's a lot to say about the human connection. As a sociologist, I gravitate toward social constructionism. The Cathedral of Notre Dame wouldn't exist if Christianity hadn't been socially constructed in a peculiar way when the builders originally started their tasks. This cathedral is the physical manifestation of a particular mutually constructed social reality in a particular place at a particular time.

But as a futurist, I gravitate toward social constructions and how they change over time. The agony so many people felt watching images of a magnificent building burning shows how much of the meaning we make of life today -- and which we project into the futures we create -- is anchored in our shared pasts. Those shared pasts may be real or imagined, but the fact that we share images of a common past anchors us in time.

I have my doubts that the cathedral will be restored exactly as it was. Not only are there changes to the materials and techniques we have available, but there are social changes as well. And the builders, church officials, and the people who worship there all, no doubt, have their ideas of how it ought to be. Whatever they do, however, will last far into the future. So, to me, the biggest question is: what do they want this monument -- this living representation of what Catholicism is and should be -- this living monument of Paris and Parisian life -- is and should be, both for people living today and those who will celebrate nine centuries of life after the fire.

Voices change over time. That's OK, as long as they remain true to who the speakers are at the moment they speak.
Speak the truth in love after our example in Christ.

COMMENT FROM A PARISIAN WITH A TASTE FOR HISTORY
My comment will be drowned into the depth of the 5000+ already posted comments I am afraid, and it surely echoes other comments already made. But in spite of my personal agreement with the general point of your video, I think that there are several illustrating examples you chose that are in fact off-the-point, and the Notre-Dame issue is one of them. Let me elaborate.

It is true that there has been an outbreak of indignation in France (and elsewhere) at the mere idea of changing a single thing to the architecture of Notre-Dame after the fire. I understand where this feeling comes from, and it comes out of a good place: preserving the voice of the past as it was. Now, the trouble is: that voice, as we perceive it, NEVER really exited. We see Notre-Dame as this timeless piece of architecture that bridges a nearly 1000-years gap between people who shared the same human nature as we do. But no more than anything that we human build, be it physical objects or concepts, Notre-Dame is not timeless and cannot be.
First, a you said yourself, the cathedral was built over a 200+-year period. This is ample time for architectural tastes and theological and practical priorities to change. But more than that, ALL European cathedrals have been undergoing constant refurbishing and repurposing throughout the hundreds and hundreds of years of History they went through. In the case of Notre-Dame, the largest changes that were made emanated from the so-called Romantic period of the middle of the XIXth century, where a renewed interest for the Middle-Ages appeared. Therefore, the Notre-Dame that we know and love is, really, not a testimony of the architectural taste of the XIth century in France, but a testimony of the way people from XIXth-century France IMAGINED the Middle Ages to be.

So, the question is: with a building that has spanned a thousand years, and whose very structure bears the mark of the varying tastes of people during that time span, which version should be the "true" one ? Were do you put the cursor ? In that way, ancient buildings are a little like languages: they both bear traces of an ancient, almost timeless past, and at the same time are constantly evolving through their everyday use and the changes of taste of the successive time periods.

It is important to keep snapshots of things as they are, as a memory (and now that we can do that). But willing to "freeze" things in time as a testimony of the past is doomed to fail. After all, Notre-Dame showed us that not even stone is timeless.

There’s two things I found interesting about this. Firstly, cathedrals like Notre Dame are extraordinarily vast given their age. The people who planned it and laid the foundation stones would never have lived long enough to see it completed. The scale of such buildings is such that there’s constant building maintenance going on. You could say that, from the first stone to this day, builders have never really left.

The second point is that those glass negatives are almost certainly 5 x 4 inches, a format that is still in use today. 5 x 4 and 10 x 8 large format cameras are still used for architectural and studio photography, especially where poster-sized images are required. Even in this digital age, larger formats provide for incredible detail and detect a range of colours that normal cameras can’t.

Trying to preserve memories, such as the Notre Dame church, is a noble thing we do for next generations. The problem is that nothing in life is static, everything changes and transforms into something else. One could argue whether the reconstructed church is the same as the old one, since most things are new, just made to look like they were like the original. Making another analogy, not even our bodies are the same as it was 10 years ago. All cells have been replaced. It's as if we had a new body.

Change is the essence of life itself. We wouldn't be here if it wasn't for this trait. And I find it ironic to try to defend things should always be kept as they are.

You are making a really important point, because you are, in a way, talking about learning to be content. (pun possibly intended)
What it comes down to for me in discussions about this is the incredible quote from the game Portal:

"We do what we must...because we can."

It captures something very human for me. We are really good at optimizing and min-maxing, which allowed us to solve many crucial problems, and to enjoy a level of convinience in our everyday lifes that was unthinkable in the past. But there are always instances where the optimization becomes it's own end, instead of being a means to an end.
It becomes a hamster wheel of senselessly chasing the next thing, in many different forms. It can lead to a very skewed sense of worth, for yourself and things around you, and to very hollow meaningless pseudo-innovation. You only really notice it, if you manage to step out of it and ask: "Wait...why are we doing this? Why do we need this? DO we need this?".

I feel the need to clarify that this statement is not supposed to be anti any one practice or system in particular (e.g. capitalism). I think a discussion about that would miss the point. I rather believe humanity needs to learn to value moderation in general, if we are to "grow up" as a species.

As some French existentialist philosopher ( sorry I cannot remember the name)  said that you cannot interact with the world without immediately imposing your opinion onto the thing you are interacting with. I think it is normal to react in a way you did not think before after being exposed to new information/experience etc. whether that be finding the patter in length of videos vs views or anything else. I liked this video and appreciate the message, though it did get me thinking about the example of Notre Dame. I don't think that the idea of changing the interior to make it more suitable for tourists should be dismissed out of hand.

For one thing, it would hardly the first time that Notre Dame has been disneyfied. The cathedral was "restored" in the mid 19th century during which a lot of the iconic elements of the cathedral were added for the first time, including the spire which burned down in 2019.

Also, from a more practical view point, millions of people visited Notre Dame Cathedral every year and once the restauration is complete, that will be true again, regardless of whether the interior is changed or not. From a conservation angle, there is a lot of sense in planning ahead for these visitors. Any visit to a historical or archaeological site risks degrading it, and by creating infrastructure specifically designed to accommodate these visitors, it can help preserve the monument for future generations and save likely billions of euro in future restoration costs.

To be clear, I do think that changing the interior is most likely a cynical attempt to get more money out of the tourists that flock the cathedral (though I don't really know enough about the subject to be certain), but my point is it's not so simple as "new is bad, old is good".

I'm a fan of your channel Destin, of the last few years, but you're just wrong here, imo.
So, first, changing your behavior due to external factors, that's called life. I don't know what glass bubble you've been living in, but everyone's journey is going to be determined by circumstance and free will, in that order. For example, it is pure circumstance that all your best friends were even born (much more likely, a different person would have been born), but then you made the best of the situation you were in by choosing the best friends you could out of who was available. And this is not a bad thing, because ours brain can't cope with infinite possibilities.
Second, making the content you want to make and making the content that performs well is not an either-or, even if from your perspective it often seems that way, because you are in control of what you want to a greater extent than you may realize. What I mean is, if things like length of your videos are really essential to what you want to make, then (my hot take is) you simply aren't innovating enough. There is no first principles reason why you can't tell the story you want to tell in a way that happens to please the algorithm. Short form and long form content serve different but viable roles on YouTube nowadays, and I can't help but feel like you either 1) haven't clearly identified what actually matters (like you obviously feel it, but can't write it down in a sentence), or 2) haven't accepted that the platform has changed, that demographics have changed, etc.
Third, I highly doubt that even if you ignore the algorithm entirely when you make the video, you wouldn't still be influenced by it indirectly. Because the community who watches must go through that algorithm, and their feedback get you to change the next video. And dude, if you won't listen to feedback from anywhere, then I mean, that's not protecting your voice, that's just talking to yourself.
Anyway, rant ending with this: Knowing who you are is not about controlling or ignoring external factors. Those external factors turn into opportunity, skill, and character with the right mindset. Knowing who you are is about identifying your values, and using that to set a destination (a firm goal with only the most important stipulations) or trajectory (an algorithm that you filter your actions through) for your life. Once you have your destination or algorithm, accept that most things in life are out of your control, and just course correct on the way. Knowing what you want is only possible if you know yourself really well, so focus on figuring out who you are before making sweeping changes to your projects.
Hope this helps someone. This is stuff that I figured out and learned from mentors, and has helped turn my life around.

Svetlana Boym (a scholar on nostalgia and memory) writes about the Sistine Chapel in the same way you talk about the Notre Dame in her book "The Future of Nostalgia." She talks about the restoration of the Sistine Chapel and how post-restoration most visitors remarked they thought the updated version looked garish and ugly. Restorers came to realize that the the patina that accrued over centuries informed modern phenomenological engagement with the art, and the distaste of post-restoration visitors emphasizes that they were nostalgic for the aged version of the art, not the art as it stood in its early years. Boym also notes that the methods of painting on the ceiling suggest that Michelangelo anticipated the collection of dust and soot and painted in such a way that the work would improve with time.

Famous Russian movie director Andrey Tarkovsky wrote a book "Sculpting in time". He basically treated the time as a physical medium in his works, calling movies a "mosaic from time", where you put together a time pieces in a long, consecutive feature. His movie "The Mirror" (1974) is the pinnacle of this approach, where you have most important memories from a first point memory experience put together as a full length motion picture.

There is a tragic story of negatives here in Australia. In the mid 20th century departments would fundraise by buying up collections of glass negatives and scraping off the emulsion to recover silver. This was in an era where photographic studios would often keep the negatives they process on behalf of clients. The glass was subsequently recycled into fire alarm boxes which were designed around 3.25x4.25” negatives. Every public building had physical wires back to fire stations, and a triggered alarm would light up a display board. Trucks would carry glass to reset the system after false alarms.

I do feel short videos have their place, just as long videos do, but you're absolutely right that algorithmic benefit shouldn't be the driving factor for your content. Youtube needs to burn their algorithm and stomp on the ashes, though. While individuals like you may buck the trend and resist those urges, those urges are the trend. Especially now that it's many people's livelihood rather than just an art project. The algorithm, like cable TV, the music industry and many others before it, creates a monoculture where only the largest demographic is actually served, and everyone else just has to sort of cope with it or find things out on the niches.

To some extent the cycle of niches growing to mainstream and turning other things into niches is a natural result of a market. But it's not healthy and leaves the majority of people underserved outside of the transition periods like the early days of Youtube.

With the capabilities of an algorithm driven system, Youtube could do better within its own microcosm. They can identify things like propaganda, science denial, and scams to some degree, and create a subset of your recommendations that is outside of what you normally watch. Maybe 1 in 50 recommendations is something from a political bubble outside the one you create for yourself, or 1 in 30 is something from a genre you haven't watched before (but also haven't told it to avoid). "Popular" has a place in the recommendations, but it can also include expanding our horizons or getting outside of our comfort zone a little.

On the other side of that, though, the BULK of recommendations should be based on what you've actually watched and what you've said not to show. As many channels as I've clicked "never recommend", I should never see a sports or major pseudonews punditry network (CNN, Fox, etc.) recommendation ever again, but they never go away. This is the worse Youtube problem, frankly, of actively suppressing niches.

Yeah, I've never watched any shorts (or as I like to call them, "sh*rts") that really had any value over a longer video. Especially when they're trying to shoot anything that would be better framed landscape rather than portrait. In fact, there's one YouTuber I watch who refuses to shoot portrait, but still occasionally uploads short videos, and I think they're better than shorts because they're not constrained to the format and length. If they need to go longer than a minute, they can.

I also noticed a trend when shorts were first introduced, which was cutting up longer videos and condensing them down. After watching a few of those, it became really apparent that the original videos were much better. So now I pretty much ignore them and just watch the normal videos.

My sweet spot for video duration is under 25 minutes, that way I can fit it in a lunch break at work. 10 to 15 minutes are also good since I can just about fit two of those in. Longer videos aren't great since I'd have to wait till I go home and there's a chance they wouldn't show up in the feed again and I'd have to remember to check my subscriptions list.

I used to only watch videos from my subscription list, but I've moved to using the homepage since the algorithm ignores clicks from the subscription list, so it doesn't help with allowing the video to get found by others.

In a way I miss the old days when a "viral video" meant a video would be entertaining enough on its own merits that people would share it with their friends, which would make it spread. You know, like a virus. Now it just means a video that happened to game the algorithm into putting it on the homepage for people who aren't logged into YouTube. The videos don't necessarily have to be good or entertaining, they just have to convince the algorithm to put them on the homepage. And it easier to game the system with shorts, since the algorithm is so biased towards them because they make YouTube more money.

What an interesting take on things. I'm in my 50's and it's amazing to hear someone enthuse over physical media, such a simple a thing as a slide, a negative plate, a photograph - something that was special to us only 30+ years ago. Taking a photo on a limited medium, waiting for the film to be finished, then waiting for it to be processed - it made you think and appreciate what you were capturing. You also owned that image, the photograph and the negative - today we take images, mainly, on phones that then cloud store the file..... we no longer own it.

Imagine just how many selfies we'd be able to avoid ! Oh, we did used to take selfies, but they had far much more meaning and captured true moments.

I'm not being old fashioned, it's fun to hear the rubber band snapping back.

Something I noticed in the old versus new photographs was how the trees had grown or had been cut down. That reminds me of here in New England, there are a lot of old stone walls that I've heard used to be the borders between farmland like you might see in an old English countryside, except here the forests have exploded around them so what might have been vast fields during colonial times are now dense forested areas. Last week I went for a short hike in New Hampshire and came across some  dilapidated stone foundations, likely hundreds of years old, in the middle of the forest with trees growing all around and inside then. It's fascinating to imagine what kind of geography must have existed back when these were houses with people living in them, and that almost all trace if their existence had been wiped out and returned to nature.

We as a society are losing the concept of the human touch or human interaction. Example, it used to be that you went to the corner market that you parents and grandparents went to. You were probably friends with the cashier's son or daughter. If you got in trouble at school your mom probably got the info/411/down low/gauge from the cashier on her way home from work. And you were in deep trouble when she walked in the door. Fast forward 60 years, you can walk into a national chain grocery store shop for for whatever it is you need, check out and never interact with any person that works for the retailer. In fact, you can go online order all of your groceries, put into a designated parking stop and someone will bring out your purchase and load them into your car. And, you can even order your groceries online and have them delivered to your house. We need to get back to interacting with people. We have let our fear separate us from each other. Just my humble opinion.

The flip side of the argument regarding Notre Dame is that so much was destroyed, that trying to put it back the way it was is ultimately just making a modern copy.  Is making a modern copy of something ancient any more authentic than just using the destruction as an opportunity to modernize?  In my opinion, not really.  It'd just be faux medieval.  Furthermore, Notre Dame has been renovated before.  During WWII some of the stained glass windows were damaged and replaced with more modern designs.  The pipe organ was replaced with a computerized system.  One of the spires was added in the 19th century.  One of the things that makes Notre Dame interesting is that it embodies the history of France because it has evolved continuously for almost 1000 years.  The current renovations are just one more evolution of something that's been around for a long time.  Part of being old is that you endure tragedy.  You grow, you change, you evolve.  The Cathedral didn't stop being the cathedral. It just did what it's always been doing.

I found it interesting that you repeatedly used the term, "humanity of the moment," and regretted that you had not captured it.

There is a German word, "zeitgeist," which means "spirit of the time," or "spirit of the moment." It refers to things that give you some sense of having been present at an earlier time. I always like slides and negatives - if they are originals - because the slide or negative you hold in your hand was actually present at the place and time when the picture was taken. The silver on that film was chemically changed by photons that actually bounced off of or were emitted by the things being photographed. Those slides were THERE. And so when you hold them, view them, or even just know that you possess them, that is a connection to the time and place - zeitgeist.

I also sorta don't agree with the analogy with the Notre Dame. You even mention in your video that the cathedral has gone through many changes in its past; surely a lot of those changes were not intended by the people before and at the time. And if we really wanted to keep something static, surely opening it up for people to look at isn't the right direction anyways, right? We should just put it in a giant vacuum and seal it tight.

That's why I don't think the issue is preservation but proliferation, and in that sense I don't think it's quite right to compare the idea of expanding the restored cathedral for more eyes (even if it's for the money), to the mystifying and bullheaded decisions youtube makes on its platform. Our knowledge and understanding and our memories aren't static, so we shouldn't expect the physical world to either, even if we think it's a bad thing.

I agree that you shouldn't change yourself in cynical ways that sacrifice your voice or sense of self, but I also think that you WILL change, whether you want to or not, and resisting any change at all is equally unhealthy. It precludes growth. Preserving old works as a window into time also has value, but I also think that what it was that those works spoke to and were informed by, may simply no longer be what we get out of them now, and there is no shame or loss in re-interpreting them or moving past them, or when they are lost, creating a new version that expresses what they mean to us now. Imagine if architecture had never changed beyond one or two story wattle and daub buildings in Paris. We never would have had Notre Dame.

Thank you for this wonderful video. As a history professor up here in Clarksville, Tennessee I completely relate with your sentiments about how we capture and shape the past. You simply cannot boil everything down to easy to digest sound bites. I think the reality is that it shouldn't be easy to digest. Anyway, I wanted to share something I use in my modern world history classes. At a previous institution I had a student approach me after teaching a class on WWI. She commented that her mother flipped houses and found an old photo album in an attic in upstate New York. It turns out was an album an American brought back from the war. I can imagine him showing it to his family as he tried to explain his experiences. It starts off with the trip over, then the basics of the battlefields, but it progressively gets worse as he experiences the horrors of the war. I can imagine the shock of his family as they see the descent. The cool thing is that it is unfiltered and un moderated. There is no commentary and very few descriptions. I was able to scan the album, covers and all, and now I use it in class to have the students try to understand the experiences of the soldier. I want them to be as close to that soldier's voice as possible without the modern explanations or expectations. I think that's what you're advocating here, and although it is difficult, messy, and sometimes takes more time than we want, the act of really thinking and staying true to our own voice is incredibly important. Thanks for the video and the thoughts it provokes. I always look forward to your content.

I miss film photography so much. I studied photography at college and university (Reading and then at the Uni of Westminster in London) at the dawn of the switch to digital. My favourite cameras were medium format that had a much larger negative than the standard 35mm which digital cameras mimic, but the images I created with the huge 5x4 cameras were epic. The fun you could have printing from them and doing creative projects such as printing direct to paper was so fulfilling. Over the years the amount of quality pictures I take has reduced significantly as digital is just too easy, I don’t get the same pleasure any more.

This was an interesting topic. The problem with photography I have found is that you can look at a picture from a certain time but you can not feel what it was like to be there. For example I can take a photo glacier field but the majestic and awesomeness  of the place does not come through. Look at any vintage photo and ask yourself what do I feel and usually it would not be the people of that time. Be who you are and not what society wants, as the poem I once had stated march to your on drum. Thank you and have wonderful week.

@ 5:54 I got my first camera when I was 3 years old. While I don't consider myself an expert by any means, part of my hobby is taking pictures in existing light with no flash. My current camera is a Cannon Rebel XT digital SLR. That being said, if you learn the abilities and limitations of even a cell phone, you can get stunning pictures from those as well. I loaned a Fujifilm point and click digital camera to a friend of mine who was going on a trip to Niagara Falls. I advised him to never use the flash. He did not listen and turned on the flash. Most of his nighttime pictures failed because of that. What I told him was no matter how it looked in the display on the camera, I could do post processing to bring out the detail, but only if he did not use the flash. This is what I mean by knowing the limitations.

I rarely dislike videos(maybe a dozen or so over the last decade), but that day I decided to start disliking videos left and right until my Recommended Videos comprised of videos like this, Veritasium, Today I Learned, VSauce, Crash Course, etc.

I didn't realize how much I missed watching 10 minute videos on why riding a bike is harder than rocket science until my feed was full of random "watch till the end" videos.

I miss the days when my Recommended feed left me feeling like a philosopher, marine biologist, surgeon, minimalist architect, virtuoso, world class Chef, Japanese Blacksmith, travel journalist etc.
Through YouTube, I learned to skateboard, play soccer and do parkour in middle school; longboard, tie a tie and p in high school; became a guitarist for my church, learned to work on cars in my driveway, got into drifting, mountain bike, weld, become a handyman to help people in trailer parks, become a really good physical trainer, play basketball, learn to cook....ALL in the timeline from my freshman year of college to today 7 years later....

Now YouTube often feels like it's borderline Tiktok.

sigh I actually got kinda sad/nostalgic while typing this up. It sucks that I feel I have to struggle to keep my Recommended Videos page from descending into another app that I dread using.

I adore collecting other people's memories. Once I bought an entire fishbowl of matchbooks from a garage sale. (I needed the matches for a project.) When I got them home I found that the lady had been using them as scrapbooks of sorts. Each little book had something written on the inner flap from that night (the restaurants she went to gave them out.) There was one where she mentioned talking to a very nice man at another table when she was out with friends. Another was dated a few months later, where her friends had gotten her to go on a blind date with-surprise-that same man! Many more matchbooks later, she was describing how he proposed to her and how beautiful the ring was. There was a gap in the dates after that, I imagine they had to save a little more and couldn't go out to eat as much. But dated every year after that for their anniversary was a matchbook entry describing what they ate, what friends they were with and the presents he got her. I believe this was mid '60's. How cool is that?
