comment_text:
You know what's wild? The dislike count has been removed from YouTube for years on Google Chrome and the Android app. You can click the button but for years you've lost the ability to see how downvoted a comment is and how downvoted a video is. You have to hover over on a video to get the stat on Chrome on PC and on your phone you can't see it at all.

It's been this way for years and no one cared. People only care now because YouTube announced they were doing it despite it already being done.

That said, I think the problem to correlate to this video is that people are changing their voice to follow the crowd without knowing what is true. You only hear the uproar about the dislike button now, but it's been gone for years. That means people got influenced to change. They didn't notice it was gone years ago when it got removed.

Regarding the rebuilding of Notre-Dame: It was built over 200 years and has had at least one significant restoration in the past and I'd be shocked if there haven't been other changes over time. We tend to think of old things having always been as they are now, but that is rarely true and history of a living structure is alive as well. Old Cathedrals are rarely built and frozen in time. I'm not saying that the Notre-Dame Should be modified, but that modification is part of the history of structures that are still functioning.

This reminds me of when my grandpa passed away. We were going through pictures and found one where he was 3 (he passed at 96 for reference), a school photo when he was in the 2nd grade, his photo when he joined the military, his ribbons and medals. It was incredible and heartbreaking. My sister had a baby and I got a picture of him, my sister, my dad, and my grandpa with my phone. 4 generations in one picture and I’ve made sure to keep it in analog form also. In a calendar, photo books, prints, anything I could think of. Hopefully in 50 years or whatever, the kiddo will be just as fascinated finding that picture as I was finding my grandpa’s old photos.

Regarding Youtube culture;
change is a natural part of life. As technology, society and our surroundings change, so will the platforms we use.

Youtube has two choices; it could stay still and inevitably become less relevant, or change and hope to stay on top. So the only logical business move is to adapt. And, on a smaller scale, the same rules apply to its creators. Everything has a life cycle, a high-point in its career, a Kondratiev curve. So it's either go with the flow or lose momentum.

That being said; even if this or any other current creator will eventually not be as relevant as competing channels, that doesn't mean they're worth less to their individual consumers for it. Quality does not always equal quantity. There's enough place for everyone on this site, and you only have to change if your end goal is continuous growth. If your end goal is to create things/videos you (and by proxy your viewers) can deem valuable, you can take pride in your actual product instead of needing to find comfort in your ever-growing numbers, which is, ultimately, a much healthier outlook on life.

Youtube as a company has no choice; to support itself and pay its employees, it must change to stay relevant. Don't get me wrong; I hate shorts, I think it's a waste of time and things like deleting the dislike button is definitely not the change I want to see on this platform.

Still, Youtube must and will change over time like it has over the last 16 years. But we as people - you, as creators - do have that choice. If you have the financial freedom to not worry too much about growth anymore, you can always decide for yourself.

So in conclusion - being willing to change is good, but staying true to oneself is just as great.

Thank you Destin for sharing your memories with us. After your film video, I got back into shooting analog film, I started off with finishing a roll that had been loaded in my soviet era SLR camera for a few years and then before I knew it I got two more film SLR cameras (EOS 650 and EOS 500 "Kiss"), a lens I absolutely adore (28mm - 105mm 3.5/4.5f USM), a bulk loader full b/w film (Ilfords HP5+) and a negative folder full of memories. I think just this year I've processed myself over 20 rolls of film including both black and white and colour.

To this day it's still magical when I process the film (or get it processed) and rediscover moments/memories that I had forgotten.

Now time for me to give back :)

Those glass plates are most likely known as "wet plate photography", basically it was how they did photos back in the day before celluiod and acetal film became mainstream. Here is something to blow your mind, when a photographer went to do wet plate photography, it was quite the ordeal, they had to take the photo, while the plate was still wet!. So they'd have to often have a portable photo lab with them so they could prepare the plates in complete darkness, load them into the large format camera, then take the photo and then (I think) process them, all while the plate is kept wet. So to have a field photograph, that is something special, most glass plate photos were taken in studios because they had all their stuff setup in the darkroom adjacent to the studio.

Something that Technology Connections' taught me was that if you play with the lighting on those glass plate photos, they are actually a positive. If you let them catch the light just right, they fell out of vogue because they only really worked if the lighting was just right.

I strongly suggest looking at Technology Connections' videos about analog photography as he covers medium format, glass plate and 35mm in his usual insane depth.

Fascinating! There's SO much to unpack and think about here. In the same way that we each have our own voice, we also each have our own perspectives when listening to another's voice. In my case, that perspective is this:
I have studied both the history of image-making (primarily cinema, but also still photography) AND the history of architecture. So I was wearing both of those hats--or both of those pairs of ears, if you prefer--as I was watching and listening.
There IS something utterly fascinating about what's called "found footage" in the cinema world--or "found images" in the case of the slides and plates you have acquired. They are physical artifacts. They are the images ON those artifacts. And they are also, as you delve into, memory. There is a very large body of research and thinking about images and memory. I could go on for ages, but I'll just leave it at that.
Something I'd like to explore a bit more is the history of Notre Dame. As you say, it was built over a very long period of time. In a way, it's possible to argue that it has been under CONTINUOUS construction, renovation, and change ever since the cornerstone was laid in 1163. The building is almost 1,000 years old. It's very tempting for us to think of it as "permanent", "fixed", or "immutable", but nothing could be further from the truth. It has changed countless times. It's just that those changes (typically) happen over such long periods of time that they become almost invisible to us. Sudden, drastic changes, like the fire, are of course different. During the French Revolution, it was gutted, used as a warehouse, and fell into almost ruin. It came very close to disappearing. Victor Hugo's "The Hunchback of Notre-Dame" (just "Notre-Dame de Paris" in French) was written as a desperate plea to save it--and it worked. The "restoration" made MAJOR changes--most famously, the spire by Viollet-le-Duc. At the time, it was HUGELY controversial. But it became one of the great symbols. It was, of course, the collapse of the spire which was the most shocking aspect of the 2019 fire...even though the spire was in no way "original"! So the history of buildings in general, and this building in particular, is complicated.
As far as "reconstruction" or "restoration" is concerned, it's once again complicated and controversial. There was an architectural design competition. Some of the proposals were radically different--just as Viollet-le-Duc's had been in the 19th century. It got very controversial. A bill was introduced requiring it to reproduce the Viollet-le-Duc design, and that's what is now planned. Personally, I think that missed an opportunity to add yet another new chapter to the ongoing and living history of the building, but the replica argument won the day. Perhaps the open question is this: is a replica the "same" as the original? How does it affect the voice of the building? How does it affect the collective memory?

Part 1. I too used to develop my own 35mm B&W photographs. I learned the skill for this from my granddad, who was a professional photographer (circa 1930-1940). He used 4X5 & 8X10 view cameras and I had no way to enlarge them, so I made contact prints. I LOVED the detail and extremely fine grain in the contact prints even when he used Kodak TRI-X® film and pushed it to around 700-800 ASA.
Part 2. I have had tinnitus for at least 60 years, and about 6 months ago I contracted covid and lost 100% of my hearing in my left ear, and my hearing was monaural, it is much better now but, I am slowly learning to hear in stereo again. The recordings in France were amazing!

If for some reason you decide that "shorts" are the right thing for you, I hope you will at least put them on a different channel.

I don't think the narrative of "updating" Notre Dame when rebuilding has to be seen through the lens of changing for the purposes of increasing appeal. It could just as easily be about improving the space for its Mass goers, tourists, or both. (But wow, the inside is very different looking from when I last visited, the booth is completely new and those panels on the walls are...interesting. Audio-wise it sounds a lot...louder and more echoey but the acoustics are probably all messed up from needing to rebuild, and I don't think I've ever been there while Mass was being held) In contrast, youtube pushing people to make shorts isn't to help the viewers or producers, it's purely to force their users to produce as much free content for them as possible, or else get buried by the algorithm. I guess in short I think the two are apples and oranges even if they look similar on the outside.

And I don't think your voice has changed since I started watching you however long ago it was. Your videos are getting longer because the things you want to talk about require a deeper dive to really communicate what's on your mind. I have seen very few short format things that really satisfy me because they simply can't explain a thing in such a short time. There have a few I have liked, but that was because the concept was an easy one to fit into a short chunk when looked at in a vacuum. Most of the rest of the ones I've liked felt more like teasers for a longer video (and in at least one youtubers case that is basically what they are, though he keeps all his shorts on a separate channel from his main one, possibly as his own way to buck youtubes trend of pushing shorts)
Always have, and always will, love that I can watch every second of every Smarter Every Day video because there is absolutely no filler. Wish more creators were like that.

I think it's interesting that you bring up memory as a concept with regards to the cathedral, because we like to think of memories as a record of events but studies show that at least in people that it's more of a motivating structure that has a lot of plasticity, but wields itself with the authority to influence your future decisions. In that way we can view the cathedral right before its fire as a somewhat faithful representation of what we all think a 700 year old building must've looked like. As the records show, the building had to be renovated and repaired many times since its original construction, and so carries a sort of Ship-of-Theseus status even when the effort is wholly directed at historical representation. I also don't really agree with changing it, but not because I disagree with change full stop, just that the motivation for change and its relationship with the way the building interfaces with people of today and tomorrow should be done in good faith, no pun intended.

@smarterEveryDay Hello Destin, just to explain that Notre Dame de Paris does not belong to the catholic church. This Cathedral belong to the French state thru the French governement, and it is only used for free by the catholic church as part of the 1905 french law about the split between churches and state (any religious monuments built before 1905 belong to the state, using taxes money to make maintenance and repairs), and are left free of charge for the church that it serve to. So the choice of the way to repair Notre Dame is a decision of the French state. Obviously the catholic church will be consulted, but the final decison will be of the state.

So while I personally don't care for shorts, I do think you might be "throwing the baby out with the bathwater" here. Sure your content would never work on a platform like TikTok, YouTube isn't looking to become TikTok. Shorts aren't meant to replace the longform video content, rather to supplement it. And while a channel could exist on youtube that is nothing but shorts, in the spirit and style of TikTok, to dismiss them outright because the majority of content on platforms like that tend to be more mindless, dumb entertainment is maybe a bit short sighted.

Right now, you cover a wide range of topics, and the 10 million of us subscribed to your channel love it. But what about all of the other users who may see a 30 minute long video about visiting the coast guard, or diving deep into how a carburetor works and think "nah, not interested". There could be people skipping right past a topic that could become their passion purely because they don't want to spend 20, 30, 40 minutes or more to "get to the point". Whereas, a 60 second video that condenses the idea down to its most basic concept in a way that makes it intriguing just might get them interested enough in the topic to put in that 20, 30 or 40 minutes to learn more.

Don't fall into the trap of seeing "the medium is the message". The best artists and creators have always been those who are able to work within the limits of a medium without letting the medium define their message. Already there are people on TikTok tackling complex ideas in shortform videos in ways that intrigue and inspire more learning. Just look at the whole wellerman hype that happened last year. Adam Neely was able to take it and create an entire video that dove deep into the topic and history of Sea Shanties and within that very video he had examples of people on TikTok exploring interesting musical ideas.

I'm not trying to say you should do shorts. You do what you want to do, it's worked well enough to get 10 million people to subscribe. What I am saying, however, is that maybe you could revisit the idea of what a short is without assuming that TikTok is the end all, be all of what that medium is capable of being, and maybe you'll see a challenge in it to make the short something more meaningful, instead of just letting it continue to be mindless, dumb entertainment.

I understand your comparison with Notre Dame, but it's not quite the same. You're talking about changing future content. Changing Notre Dame is changing past content. It's as if you were to take down all your videos, edit them, and re-upload them.
And it goes even deeper than that. A lot of people enjoy your content, but I would argue that it is not comparable to the level at which people enjoyed Notre Dame. Whilst loads of tourists have visited it and then went on their merry way, never quite thinking about it again, for some it has been life changing. For some, visiting it often is life changing. And they have had that taken away from them. It's not a simple act of moving with the times. To me, it sort of feels like betrayal. Like the people who worshipped there or who gained spiritual welfare from seeing it have been dealt a devastating blow when it burnt down, and now they received a new blow when they were told: "Yeah, we could rebuild it... but we won't."
Our culture is valuable, despite what newer generations may claim. Taking away cultural icons from people is not quite the same as not giving them new ones.

I used to teach History and I always posited to my class that Time Travel exists. For a moment they were all puzzled…so I would elaborate.

With the advent of 360° cameras, HD video, binaural audio recordings, and VR we have all the pieces required to transport people back to actual moments.

Set aside the “Big Brother” implications for a moment, but imagine if this equipment was set up for special occasions (eg inaugurations, concerts, speeches, protests, etc). Then fast forward to a much later date. Someone could put on a high quality VR headset and headphones and be transported to those moments.

It was always a great thought experiment and kids were so enamored with the idea of how their “fun” technologies could be unlocked for so much more!!

“ We are curating our lives”… you’ve basically described the work of influencers… right? YouTube is only a platform as long as it’s relevant. And it’s only relevant if people watch. Perhaps the audience should become more discerning so as to prompt the success of genuine content. The algorithm is (ultimately) slave to the culture… maybe we are just too shallow?

Notre Dame: What you have technically done by editing the footage with A.I. and software, is: altering the recorded memory towards what you think the observer may have experienced and could not have been recorded due to the deficiencies of the recording device. Thus the recorded memories don't really depict the actual memories. And also: If the observer looks back at it after a period of time, his memories will alter, too. Also, the old slides definitely only show what the photographer was able to or willing to show. That should be kept in mind when looking back at the past and try to understand "what it was (supposedly) back then".

I'm not a Christian, so I have even less say over what is done with the Cathedral (I was really saddened when I saw what happened!). But I want to share that something like Notre Dame that was built over the course of about 200 years and lasted for over 600 years is not something that should be changed or upgraded.

Could you imagine if they decided to update the interior of the Great Pyramids to be more attractive to modern crowds? Or what if they decided to paint all the Terracotta Warriors to appeal to a wider audience? Widen the Great Wall of China to allow more tourists? Liven up the colors in the Sistine Chapel to reflect modern tastes? Gave the Mona Lisa a makeover so her "makeup" was more inline with today's beauty standards?

Treasures like this are part of our history and need to be preserved as they are. I don't care if it's something that has great religious significance like Notre Dame, something that was built in a time of war, or a piece of art. These things are important to our human culture. Preserve them, but don't change it.

So I wonder if your objection to the cathedral is more of a "ship of Theseus" concept? You believe (I assume) that by rebuilding it as it was, we have preserved the intent and thus the memory of the original building. So you would see it as being preserved/restored. However, I see that cathedral as gone; its history ended. Everything we do at this point is a facsimile of the original, but NOT the original. So I have no objection to making it different inside. Put glittering LED bulbs all over the outside and pink trim. It matters not, because you are not disrespecting the original architects or building. They are dead, and Notre-Dame de Paris is destroyed forever. Sometimes we need to make peace with the past and move on, and not try to keep everything as it was in perpetuity. IMO.

-- EDIT --
Also, this reminds me of the star trek transporter philosophy. See, I believe it murders the original and makes a copy. Given your video, I have to believe you think it would relocate them.

I think you make a valid point, and changing yourself to please the whims of an algorithm or a fickle society is a dangerous game.  However, as I watched your video, I was struck by how there is a fundamental assumtion that your "voice" is infallible and correct (I'm not trying to say that you believe yourself to be infallible,  you have proven yourself to be a humble and open-minded person, which is why I thought it important to raise this point).   There may be some individuals who hold extremist views, but are swayed by the common sense of the statistically normal, and leave behind their "voice" of bigotry or violence.  I would argue that, in some ways, it is the purpose and responsibility of a constructive society to help bring those extremes out of their standard deviations and toward the mean.  I still feel there is room for individualism and personality within that "normal", so a "voice" is still maintained, but that the shifting or tempering of that voice is not necessarily always a bad thing.

Destin, good luck to you as you work to balance the "don't lose your voice" with the "get my voice heard".  Playing to the algorithms doesn't have to result in losing your voice, and a lot of the stuff you produce needs to be heard by as many people as possible.  Tough balancing act I know.  Onward HO!

There's a balance there to capture the design of something that was created in a period, but there's also no reason why you shouldn't add an extra room because your family is bigger or that you should still using an outhouse.

To bring it back to YouTube, you should absolutely do what you want to do and keep your voice, but there are good changes to make outside of appeasing the YouTube recommendation system, such as moving to 4k or tweaking your content to match what your audience's interests. Everything is a balance and I think it's important to not swing too far to either extreme.

Just two days before Notre-Dame burned, I was in Paris on a school trip in Europe where we explored different important places from WW2. I was standing in front of the Notre-Dame but decided not to go in due to long lines and time constraints (this was a school trip after all). I remember after we’d moved on from Paris and were in Belgium, watching on TV as the spire of the cathedral fell, engulfed by the flames. My biggest regret then and now was not taking the time to go inside and see it with my own eyes. It was right there, and though it’ll be rebuilt, I would never be able to see and feel how it once was myself. This video allowed me to at least get some feel for what it was like, and for that I thank you, Destin.

I want to suggest a photographer I think you will like. Garry Winogrand was an American street photographer that really captured moments of human existence.  His quote, "I photograph to see what the world looks like in photographs." sounds like what you are saying.  At the time of his death his late work remained largely unprocessed, with about 2,500 rolls of undeveloped film, 6,500 rolls of developed but not proofed exposures, and about 3,000 rolls only realized as far as contact sheets being made. In total he left nearly 300,000 unedited images. Could you imagine if he was around in the digital photography age where you can take nearly unlimited amounts of pictures?

Great topic.  We went to China back in 1988 when, as a tourist, you could only travel in groups.  It was a great trip and stayed for about 3 weeks going to many places. I even have a picture on the great wall where there is no one - which is very difficult to get now.  Across the river in Shanghai it was basically all farm land and now it has all the modern high rise buildings. Regardless, I give you my respect that you are trying your best at what you consider to be good mainly for the sake of others before yourself. Most of your content happens to require thinking; hence somewhat of a longer length makes more sense than shorts. Shorts have their place if the message conveyed doesn't do it any good for being longer.

I think that part of what you meant by "don't loose your voice" is don't loose your moral "conscience". And I like that. We are just too focused to liking to the feeling of "winning"; whether it is money, arguments, being correct or whatever. So much to the point it becomes greedy. And greediness is not always just about wanting more, it can sometimes be about wanting one thing. But we become so greedy that we want that one thing in our own personal and ideal way.

The point is, we need to make sure that being busy with the things happening around us, won't make us loose that touch of our conscience.

It is important to "keep your voice", yes, but also to change & grow.
Life is iterative, after all, & even the Scientific Method is based on that fact.
All things change, from mountains to religions, & stagnation is to court death.
You, who can choose your voice, have a great luxury most will never have.

Justin, This video is very nice on many levels. You, however, started with a premise that is invalid. Your beginning comparing "Making changes to N.D. to handle large numbers of people" is unrelated and misplaced. A building like N.D. is more than a work of art to view, it is a multi-function machine, which is in addition to its beauty and appearance. If you reject building changes to handle crowds you should compare Youtube improving its logon ease and load time.  Your rejection of pandering to an algorithm is completely valid. Emmanuel Macron stated that the cathedral will "look" exactly like before. This can certainly preclude inclusion if the 400 tons of lead which were melted in the fire. Other functional changes can be included to give easier access to the structure. If you had watched President Macron on many occasions pledge consistency in aesthetics, you would celebrate functional changes for access to keep the historic beauty in place. You could then state your voice will be heard just like Notre Dame beauty will still be available.

There was a Louis Rossmann video that i recently watched where he was talking about losing sight of your goals and the dangers of not having a "Mission statement" where he talked about his journey on how he started out with his business, and he was talking about how he tried to expand his supply business by competing with people on Ebay or Amazon where the expectation isn't on the Quality but on Quantity/Cheap prices.
He already had customers for his business but they liked him because the quality of the products he supplied were high, and that made him a trustworthy supplier, but Afterwards as he was trying to compete with Ebay/Amazon etc. sellers, his products went down in quality and he realized that he was fighting an uphill battle against Giants there, while also losing his previous customers who wanted only the best quality products. And that's why he only focuses on things he wants to do in his business now, I think it's a really nice story on knowing what you want with your Product/Website and focusing on it instead of trying to be Everything at once and only realizing it once it's too late. It's even a nice lesson on a personal level because we're humans, it is simply impossible for us to do everything on our own, So take your time, plan your future and be safe.

It’s funny that younger the example of Notre Dame. Ever since it burned in 2019 it became a symbol to me. It’s undoubtedly a milestone of construction and a monument for the religion and the time it was constructed. The obvious reaction to this catastrophe was devastation and pain as it has always been part of the reality I lived in for the past 27 years. But then I started thinking, isn’t it also part of the reality that things evolve, grow, fall apart and rise again? Would it be right to keep something from evolving, growing or falling apart? Isn’t everything we lose a chance for something new? I can very well understand the doubts of altering this building as it’s renovated, but I found that we all have little Notre dames in our soul. We want things to stay, yet we are most alive when these things change, sometimes in our favor sometimes not, but that’s the balance of nature. That’s why the Notre Dame became the symbol for me to never stop becoming. And if the actual cathedral has to stay at it is, it should remind ourselves that we shouldn’t. We are always on the move. Sometimes it takes a while to discover which voice to follow. And sometimes we are wrong, but we can always find a new path if we want to. I love your videos, that’s for sure. Whatever voice you listen to, I’ll be curious where it‘ll lead you and what you’ll become. Keep up😊

Everyone is entitled to their own opinion obviously (and I know this example was not the purpose of your video), but I could not disagree more when it comes to the Notre Dame example. I think it is a poor comparison, because much of the original church is now physically gone. The church as you mentioned was in the process of being built almost a thousand years ago. You cannot bring that history back it would simply be an imitation.

That is like if for example lets say all of the video's on SmarterEveryDay's channel were deleted and lost forever, fans didn't have back-up copies and neither did Destin. He could either continue making modern videos and keep his channel going, or like with rebuilding the church exactly as it was he could attempt to recreate each video trying to make it exactly as it was. Staging it in an effort to recreate history. There is a certain allure to doing something like this, in an effort to keep history alive. But it doesn't change the fact that the old videos are gone. It is very much a Ship of Theseus style debate. (Many of you may recognize this concept if you saw WandaVision, which recently re-popularized the idea, if you haven't I would recommend looking it up.)

The people of France could build something that is both new and honors the memory of what came before it. That I would argue is part of what humanity is about. Honoring the past and building a better future.

There was a photography professor at my alma mater who said something I never forgot. He said, "We are angels, not gods." He meant to distinguish photographers from other kinds of visual artists, but I think his observation is true of all creative efforts - they are about gathering and directing attention. Youtube is no different. If one allows performance metrics to dictate methods and objects of attention, the artist becomes part of a feedback loop, a literal manifestation of Ouroboros. It's not good for the creator and not good for the viewer. Preserving integrity of vision is an essential part of a healthy internet habitat. Allow me to posit a few things here:
1. Change is not always bad. Change, in fact, is necessary even as we pine for what we know better. Humans are resistant to change, but it is often inevitable. I mean, you can go back to the horse and buggy and steamship if you want, but then you couldn’t have even traversed the airport in Paris, right? Similarly; I no longer shoot film and am not enthralled with glass negatives - but I can appreciate the images captured. That, to me, is what is important - that the moment was captured. Or, alternatively, that you get to Paris in the first place. If you can do so more conveniently, all the better.
2. Some change is - in my opinion - bad. Take Dublin Castle, which has the gorgeous architecture seen in the Cathedral here but also has additions made in what appears to be 1950’s brickwork. That changes the character of it substantially and - frankly - turned me off of the whole thing. I went there to photograph it and didn’t bother. Likewise, if they introduced modern graves into Pere’ Le’chaise Cemetery in Paris, it would alter the character of it materially.
3. Having been to the Notre Dame Cathedral shortly before it burned, I can say that unless they substantially alter the character, it doesn’t matter all that much what they do. After all, the stone didn’t burn. Some things are (relatively) permanent.
4. I subscribe to YouTube content creators because of the content. Have I found every one of them that I think is valuable? Assuredly not, thanks to the algorithm. But I find them. And once I have, the quality of the content is what keeps me coming back. I don’t listen to podcasts because 99% of them have way too much fluff in them and take forever to get down to the topic at hand. One thing I AM tired of is in-content “sponsored by” ads - those are a guaranteed skip or close-out of the video if they are at the end. I get why they are there, but hey, I am paying for YT Premuim to avoid ads, only to get them in the content I am paying to watch.

One thing that kept coming to my head watching this video is the Urban Sketching movement. The idea is simply people going outside and sketching what they see in real time - with a big focus on people. I noticed some time ago that I would take lots of pictures during trips that I really didn't care for. Then I started taking a sketchboo to trips instead. You don't get as many pictures, but each one you draw counts - you get to really observe the moment, form memories and add in your voice. And if you're interested in physical objects and a human touch, you can search the internet or buy books to see these sketches instead of photographs.

Every content creator, over the years, eventually runs out of wide-interest things or events to analyse.
At that point, he/she doesn't want to loose the audience by getting into niche or specialised interests, so they delve into challenges of various nature. The most creative authors start challenging common sense.
This path can take a decade; and in my opinion this adaptive change is an error, as the content creators should accept what they have become.
In the TV parlance, they start "Jumping the shark"; exactly your fear, that you may have changed parts of yourself in order to please the YouTube algorithm, which favour spectacular content over deep analytical types.
My suggestion: jump the shark only if your channel is about marine biology. In other cases, always make a spectacle out of your thoughts, as you have just done with this video...

With out change you voice goes no where. Which is why there are 10s of thousands of channels that are stuck with low views. You have the chance to effect many more people. While sticking to your roots will keep you stalled. Changing with the times keeps your relevant. As your channel grows so does the people who watch it and they come for the stuff that found your videos in the first place. People are going to come and go. Just like I may come and go at some point. There are many channels where I longer watch them because they got stale. So if you change with the times then you will keep growing. If your baseball videos gets the most views then stick with things like that. If this video gets low views then do not do it again. I am going to guess this video will get low views.
You also have to rememebr that 10 years ago was the days when videos got 10s of millions of views. This was because there were far less channels at that time. Now there are 10s of thousands of channels who have 1m subs or more. This gives a lot more content for people to watch. Viewership has gone down for channels yet overall its much higher because its spread out.
Your channel for example has been around for a decade and in the last 5 years has seen a drastic drop in viewership. Many of your major viewed videos were 5 years or more a go with a few recent videos here and there. This is true with 1000s of channels you will find people who are still producing the same content that now garners under one million views where they used to get 10s of millions of views. This is because there are more and greater options of channels out there. Keeping with the times is the only way you will keep the views.
Sure you get an average of about 2.5 million views a video yet look at all of the videos that bombed, those videos were your keeping your voice.

I generally don't bother with shorts. I wonder how common that is? Maybe because it's not easy to measure how much shorts are ignored, platforms are over-estimating their impact. They just see that lots of shorts are consumed. My guess is that shorts don't compete with longer-format content. They address two incompatible sets of viewer "needs".

(Very long videos are another matter. I know I quite strongly favour the 15 minute range, for instance. I'll still click on longer run content, but that's largely because I know that YouTube will remember my place for me if I stop half way and go to something else. Generally if I've clicked on something that's between say 15 and 20 minutes long, I've already committed to watching it all in one go; if it's longer, I've already allowed myself to split it up. This might be unusual, but if it's not, it suggests that it might be a good idea to split things up. No need to invent new thumbnails and titles; "Part 1 and Part 2" does fine.)

While I am in support of your message of “don’t be fake”, I did have several thoughts that might be of interest. For instance, N. D. has always been changing as you said, so why not change now in the reconstruction? I personally am in favor of emergency doors that swing out, modern fire suppression systems, and flushing toilets. I’d bet the practicing Catholics would like a space that isn’t overrun with tourists, so unless they are going to limit entry entirely, it make sense to accommodate both uses of the space. Also, it certainly hasn’t always been the tourist destination it is today - that’s why Victor Hugo wrote his novel to begin with - it itself is propaganda. As for your own videos, (which I enjoy, btw), who is your audience, really? If this was really about what you personally like and want, would you care about anything you tube does? And to that end, why then produce videos at all that are the teaching/conversation to an audience? If, though, you are interested in reaching a wide number of people, you have to bow to the pressures of how that is made possible. For instance, you could be releasing all your videos in Latin, but that for sure would shrink your audience. Don’t want to do shorts? Don’t do shorts. If your content is good, it will get shared regardless. If it’s for you and your personal satisfaction, it doesn’t matter if it does - in the same way the photographer of those sides certainly didn’t take those pictures imagining what you have done with them.
Destin, don’t lose your compass bro. You’re doing fine in the medium you’ve chosen.

I agree with your premise, but changing Notre Dame is not quite the same. As you pointed out for centuries the building was update and renovated to be suited for the times. Only in the last 100-200 years have buildings like this been frozen in time. We believe we CAN'T change them... Like a Star wars action figure, it can't be taken out of it's 19th century packaging! (19th century because as I said, up until that point all buildings were renovated, often extensively.) But, we are starting to see a major problem with that. Only so many people want to see frozen in time relics. For ancient and medieval buildings to remain standing, we today must do the same things that kept those buildings standing for all those centuries: use them. That's why you see things like a stage being built in the Coliseum to host concerts and things. The building must be used, or the funding will run out, it will fall into disrepair, and one day collapse entirely.

Buildings are not people. They must be updated with the times. You tweaking your approach to gain an audience online is very different. And it is only as personal as you make it. But I understand the desire to make what you want and not be forced into this or that.

Thanks for this. We recently inherited (literally) thousands of negatives and slides, and we are somewhat overwhelmed with the decision of what to do with them. It was helpful for some of your enthusiasm to rub off, hopefully we'll be able to find the time to work it out. It's an interesting dilemma, being raised by a photographer, we treat negatives like gold. But when you think about it, most of them have no real value. You may take 20 pictures to get the one you want. And how will future generations know which one is the keeper? If you take into account that the act of printing them (in a darkroom) is as much an art form as the shot itself, the negative is only half of the equation. The process is so time consuming to go through them, it is easy to lose motivation.

I have a lot of slide photos from my grandfather. He worked as a professor of geology and geography, and took photos from all over the world, but focused nearly entirely on the features of nature in these areas... plants, geographic features, and such.

Upon his death, we donated most of those slides to one of the universities in which he taught, but I still have more, all annotated (meticulously) with where and when they were taken.

I wish I could find some way to transfer these slides, with their annotations, to some digital means by which one may search for the content, without having to devote my life to the effort (as I have much other work that I need to do, both for a career, and because others depend upon me). Digitizing the photos is one thing... but the annotations that make them valuable... hrm.

I have similar fascination of photographs, videos and audio recordings of everyday life. Our lives are short, our memories fade, but technology allows us to hold a moment in time forever. That's spectacular possibility and right now, with supercameras in our smartphones we have unprecedented situation where millions of people capture time in such detail. I cherish that. I often take a moment while doing something or nothing and just look around, hear around and think- this is perfect, life IS and I am in good health, good time of my life where I can just acknowledge the beauty of moment.

As always, wonderful video! As a Catholic Priest who is also a geek, I do think you're hitting on something with your Notre Dame analogy. When Notre Dame burned, it impacted me on two levels: One - I visited the Cathedral when I was in high school; Two - It's obviously important for the history of Christianity. When the announcement was made about making it more tourist friendly, it hit me in a weird way too. Do I want people to visit the beauty of Notre Dame? Yes! Do I want it to maintain its faith identify? Yes! There's also the tension that the life of a Christian is a lived relationship with Jesus Christ amid the community faith - Community first, buildings second. At the same time, there is something about sacred places like Notre Dame that do facilitate a faith experience. My hope is that the "tourist friendly" will be done in a way that will protect the integrity of the faith aspect of Notre Dame while allowing visitors who are wanting to see it more for non-faith reasons to have a positive experience, but not at the cost of faith. All things need to modernize - upgraded HVAC systems, security, restoration, replacement of crumbling walls, etc. But the identity or ethos of the space needs to remain consistent.

In regard to social media, I agree that keeping your voice like keeping the faith dimension of Notre Dame is important. Something I struggle with is when it becomes clear that social media as an entity itself has a "voice" or "bias" toward the controversial, inflammatory, and violent. As much as I love YouTube for things like your channel, it also worries me that social media has the ability to say to authentic voices "your voice will not be heard." I agree with you - Don't change your approach to content unless it reflects an authentic change in you. I just hope that social media will respect authenticity.

Regarding Notre Dame, it's not exactly a 1 to 1 comparison. Yes, keep your voice, yes, keep your focus, but Notre Dame is changing to be able to change with the times. The cathedral's purpose isn't the same as it used to be, there're more and more cathedrals and churches all over the place and more and more denominations that have their own voice as well, so Notre Dame is better served by the need to be kept upright through tourism dollars. The longer a thing exists, the more money it costs to make sure it KEEPS existing, and Notre Dame, like so many other places, has been around for so long that it's basically lost any sense of possibility of being modernized, whether that be for handling a group of people in the space or for handling things like accessibility concerns, which is a very real problem in a lot of older construction, narrower doorways and passages, steps and such with no wheelchair access, the list goes on. The church isn't really losing its voice by saying "We're going to make the building more accessible", they still exist as a massive cathedral and such, but they also know that they have, in this moment, and opportunity to make necessary changes that wouldn't have been possible before because they would be potentially destructive, an opportunity presented by the fact that random chance basically made those destructive changes FOR them. It's still gonna be a giant cathedral, it's still gonna have all of its majesty and everything else, but this way it can serve those who were underserved in the past, all while maintaining that voice.

In essence, to make the comparison work, it'd be like if you were working with a renderer for your videos that worked in extremely proprietary project files, but it was the best there was at the time you got it for your needs. Then, you had a major software crash that made that older piece of rendering software fail completely in a way that couldn't be fixed, not only making your older files impossible to work with, but also forcing you to change it. Now you could get the latest version of that same software, which would still be just as unable to do anything with your older files for whatever reason, or you could change it to software that works even better for your needs in the moment, which, again, would have trouble using older files, but would give you additional features like easier captioning, et cetera. Either way, the loss has already taken place, and there's nothing you can really do about the fact that the loss happened, you're just left with either going back to exactly how things were and how they worked for you way back when, or taking the opportunity to make necessary changes that would make your life, and the lives of some of your viewers, better in the process.

Before you can make the decisions you mentioned, regarding your videos, you have to decide what their purpose is.  Are they intended for education, entertainment, income, personal expression or (most likely) a combination of some or all of these things.  And, of course, if the focus becomes so tightly fixed on staying true to their purpose that no one watches, nothing is accomplished.  Balance is key.  The same is true for Notre Dame.  Before choosing any style or technique in rebuilding, they first need to make the choice of what they want it to be.  Will it be a beautiful relic and a monument to the past or a functional 21st century building?  It's the Engineering approach:  If you don't define your target, you'll never hit it.

Love your videos! This one got me thinking about a technique we have used for historic restoration work. By locating the approximate position of the camera that was used to take an old photo, we are able to deduce the sizes and positions of missing building parts and accurately re-create them. I'm not a YouTuber, but I've been a blogger since 1997 with more than 2,000,000 words published on the Internet so far and I really understand what you are saying about algorithms and voice. The one favor algorithms do for us is they are built from real data as opposed to the early days of the Web when "experts" kept telling me my posts were too long. Often algorithms are interpreted to say the same thing, but that's back to "experts" trying to use the algorithm to support what they wanted to say anyway.

The ideal post, I've been told over and over for decades, is 600 words long, while mine average around 1500 and have run as long as 4400 words. That 20 year-old 4400-word post is read by 1-2 people EVERY DAY, perhaps because it is cited in 100+ academic papers. Academic papers? But this is the Internet, home of stupid people and cat videos. No it is the home of EVERYONE. So do it your way, Destin. It's YOUR voice.

I think it's important to make this point:  it's about balance. You balance your voice with content that your audience wants to hear your point of view about. You don't have to change your thoughts and ideas but you DO have an audience and you DON'T have say what you think they want to hear but the subject itself is what you tailor for your audience but say whatever you think feel and know about that subject. Now I think that's how learning happens. I'm a pilot and was a flight instructor. The FAA publishes required reading for flight instructors called the fundamentals of instruction. In it the word "learning" is defined as "a change in behavior as a result of experience". I've always interpreted the word "experience" with a broad stroke. Reading a book, watching a video, demonstrating a technique, observing a demonstration etc are all "experiences". In my experience, learning takes TIME. NO SHORTS. Please, they're awful. That's my 2 cents.

I totally agree with you on the Notre Dame Cathedral changes.  I am Catholic and feel that it should be regarded as a church first and tourist attraction second.  Plus, I think part of what made the Cathedral so enticing, is the fact that it was so old and the internal structure of it.  Changing that would make it something completely different.  I went to Ireland on my honeymoon 25 years ago.  There was a place called Jerpoint Abbey.  They chose to not try to replicate some of the decorative aspects of the Abbey.  Rather, they just put up cement to give it the structure for stability only.  There were some very nice bas reliefs that had survived and they are more enhanced by the fact that they were no replicated.  I'm probably not making any sense anymore, but I always walk away smarter when  I watch your videos.  :)

Ubisoft has a very detailed scan of the Notre Dame in one of their Assasin's Creed games, which is also a time capsule for how it used to be. They also have Venice and other places. They are proud of the research, time and effort that went into digitally recreating entire cities to be as period correct as possible. These guys were digging up old maps, old paintings and drawings and pictures to recreate an environment that these games are based on. I's not a small feat.

Having traveled quite a bit compliments of the US Navy in the late 60's early 70's ... this struck a cord with me.  The camera and sound tie in to get a audible and visual feel of being there ... is interesting, and yet misses the mark by a lot, in the sensory experience.  I am a sensory aware person, I thrive on feeling my experiences beyond just seeing and hearing them, and yet as I look through photos and slides of my time, walking the streets of Olongapo in the Philippines, even Sydney in Australia, and a little of City B in Okinawa ... there is something missing.  Shortly after taking the photos myself, it wasn't missing, as my memories and experiences filled in the gaps, and now my imagination attempts to fill in, occasionally successfully .... but the other sense of smell of the environment ... even taste of the smokey air of the street vendors cooking monkey 'BBQ'.   Years later seeing new recent photos of especially Olongapo .... revisiting could never duplicate the lost moments.  Summing up ..... it kind of doesn't matter what is done to Notre Dame ... experiencing it in 1300 and in 2021 would be different if the structure remained the same.

So I've only watched 3 minutes. But I'd like to comment on the "Your Voice" comment. I've always been an individualist, who's very concerned about being true to myself, so the question often arises "what is my voice?" And my inescapable conclusion I have come to over my lifetime is "it depends on who I'm speaking to" my voice is different depending on if I'm speaking to my Mom or my friends or my boss, and that's not necessarily a bad thing. It enables communication and it doesn't mean I'm not genuine. It's also not necessarily a bad thing to change my voice to achieve and effect. If I were trying to motivate a colleague who is depressed, talking to them like I'm the fun loving clown of the office, might not be the best approach. So I ask (of the rest of the video) does changing your voice to reach an audience have to mean that you are losing your voice?

I think there's a huge difference between Notre-Dame and YouTube shorts. Buildings need to reflect their current usage, they charge to reflect their current use. Where as shorts is just a weird experiment by YouTube to get more visitors based on other apps around it, it's not helpful to the website. Notre-Dame is changing to reflect it's current usage, but YouTube is changing to gain usage that may well reduce its usefulness and in turn its use.

If we left every building the same for ever we'd still be living in cold, dark, energy inefficient homes. Buildings need to reflect their current usage to some extent. That doesn't mean they have to lose their history. Making them safer and more useful to the current users is not a bad thing, especially when the current building is damaged. If we were to follow the "don't change the history" mentality, we should leave Notre-Dame as a burnt out shell, because that is it's history, that is what happened to it. Simply by rebuilding it we are altering it as a building, so why not build it back better for it's current users. For example, they can replace burnt wooden structures with treated wood that has embedded fire retardant in it. Visually it'll look the same as it did before, but from a safety point of view it'll stop the building burning down again. Equally you can use the rebuilding process to integrate accessibility to wheelchair or make it safer for crowds to manoeuvre within the space.

All historical buildings have changes made to them over time. Visit any castle or palace and they'll be a model or image explaining how they grew or changed over time, with some kind of indicators telling use how they grew and when it happened.

The changes to Notre-Dame will be sympathetic to the building, they have to be. And as soon as they are made they will become a part of its history and development to reflect the changing use of the space. To reflect the current voice of the space. Just as the fire has become part of the history of the space.

Humanity doesn't stand still in the past. We remember it, but we don't live in it. And neither do our buildings, they reflect our current needs. Currently Notre-Dame needs to change to stop it burning down again and to accommodate the large crowds that visit it.

In the Notre Dame Cathedral and not losing your voice, I'd like to add a few things.
Notre Dame evolved in time. That does not mean it lost it's meaning, though. It just navigated through time, being affected by it in different ways, good, bad or neither one.
In medieval times, the facade of Notre Dame was painted. We are used to think of this naked stone as a sign of the old days classy style, but this is actually very wrong. Same thing for the sculptures of classical era Greece by the way. Recolored versions can be found, and they seem tacky to us, but that's just a cultural thing we project.
In the recent fire, a part called the Flèche de Notre Dame (the arrow) fell. That's the part that triggered all the questionning on whether it should be rebuilt the same or not for a good reason : it was not in the original Notre Dame. It was added in the XIXth century when Viollet-Le-Duc - a very famous and impactful architect of that era - got in charge of restoring Notre Dame.

Viollet-Le-Duc was one the biggest history nerds of his time, by the way. If you want to visit Castles in France some day, visit 1 or 2 iconic ones, and then visit the one of Pierrefond. It was "restored" by Viollet-Le-Duc in a way that really shows how the Medieval Time was dreamt of in the XIXth century. Real fun stuff.

The fleche's addition is a part of Notre Dame history in the XIXth in the same way.
That's raising an interesting question. Should we really try not to impact our monuments nowadays ? We kinda lost the thing for building monuments packed with history details and made to be ever lasting. XXIth century should leave a mark too, in its way. Obviously we should not replace earlier stuff, but when we have opportunity to add nowadays stuff, it feels right, doesn't it ?

Our voices are affected by our time, no matter what. It's a good thing to be aware of it and question it, but I'd argue some changes are to be accepted for the better.

Part of what you like about the large-format glass negatives is the fidelity... Even with the pixel definition of digital photography, we have nothing even approaching the DPI those large format images capture. That makes them much better suited for panning and cropping the images to find more information.

Just like the images, I've found your "voice" is all about the fidelity. Many times, I will re-watch your videos and find gems of information that I missed the 1st time through. Like the large format pictures, your "Voice" has that same quality, (which is why people enjoy watching them.)

In the end, if you do them for yourself (instead of the dreaded algorithm) you will maintain that same fidelity that you enjoy in large format pictures. Being yourself means you are compressing information gems in your videos that will, like the people shown in the large-format picture, hang out in the periphery of people's memory of the video. This will result in people going back to them again and again to find these nuggets of wonder (which will, by itself, tip the algorithm with zero effort on your part.)

As soon as you started talking about images and how they affect our perception, I perked up.
I'm a photographer, majored in photography some 30 years ago, and studied the history of photography then. Its interesting once you note how our perception of events is activated by photography, and yeah, its even more fascinating when you realize how much 'data' was captured in those early glass plates. (Only to be partially lost by the ravages of time)
Just as important is the fact that how we capture images changes what we decide to shoot. 150 years ago, you didn't shoot images of your lunch, because it took too long to set up the shot, you had to coat a plate in order to shoot it, and you had to prioritize what you shoot.
On the other hand, everyone is a much better photographer than people were 150 years ago. Not just because of the tools we have, but because we can constantly shoot images and get better. We also shoot more images of each other when we're happy, which affects not only how we see ourselves as a people, but how we feel worse when we're sad... because everyone else 'seems happy'. Right?

Again, talking about images and perception is my thing. Thanks, Destin.

About the Notre Dame:
TL;DR: I think that buildings like churches, train stations, museums should be allowed to constantly evolve and be modified since they serve a purpose. They’re different to the works of art, monuments, holy scriptures that are held within since those are actually finished works. Buildings are never truly finished.

Long answer:
I somewhat disagree, I don’t think it’s quite the same as with your channel. I think many of us forget that history never stops being made. The Notre Dame (or any historical structure that serves as a utility of some kind) isn’t a finished work in the same sense a painting like the Mona Lisa is, it’s a constantly evolving system that is added to over time. I’m not saying that it should be razed down or converted to a car park but I do think that updating it to serve the same purpose as before, but more suitably to modern needs is perfectly fine.
For example, replacing the chairs, adding new artwork, modern heating system, remodelling for greater seating capacity etc. In fact I’d guess that in 900 years time, there will be people arguing that the building should be preserved including the stuff added today because to them it’s 900 years old.
As a viewer I don't want to lose who I am either.

There is no reason to pretend that the Notre Dame of 2019 was the same Notre Dame that was finished in the 1300's.  It had been changing for most of a millennium, and even if it were reconstructed to the exact same condition it was in before it burned, it wouldn't be the same building.  It's literally no different than if the thing were reconstructed in Las Vegas.  It's no longer historical, plain and simple, however much people want it to be.  With that in mind, rebuilding it to reflect its current use only makes sense.  That doesn't mean putting a Starbucks inside, but it does mean purposeful modifications.

For YouTube, leaving Shorts aside, I think that they've removed two great things that they already had before:
1) Accessibility through community-submitted closed captioning (yes if you're a fairly well-off YouTube channel you should ideally provide your own but closed captioning in itself isn't a universal thing, some culture prefers hard caption);
2) The ability to make your own informed decision by making public reactions public, even if it doesn't guarantee to be interpreted exactly as it says on the bottle.


As for keeping buildings or statues or monuments or even cityscapes and just landscape in general I'll say that I think it depends on what they means to everyone, even though it's often sad that the ones who have the last say will always be those with enough power either material or immaterial. We've changed through so many "optimistic" and "pessimistic" phases in the course of humanity, and I think that the real question will always be the one of how to make sure that it can be sustained further forward or not, each solution with their own ups and downs and trade-offs.

When I taught college, I had many freshman confide in me that while at school they felt and acted like adults, but when they returned home for holidays they found themselves falling back into childish habits. They were frustrated because they didn't understand what was causing this. Part of what causes this is that our parents expect to hear us in a certain voice, and because humans are animals that have evolved to communicate, we instinctively speak in whichever voice we think our audience will hear best. It's natural actually for a person to have multiple voices, the different voices we use for our different audiences. Over time though, some of us do get better I think at integrating all of those voices into a single voice, but that's not true for everybody. Some people spend the bulk of their lives having multiple voices, and aren't even aware of it.

It's important to remember that for so many things, you don't own stuff, stuff owns you.

The problem with owning physical memories is that they can be lost and destroyed, and if the next person that comes along doesn't know what they represent, they stand a good chance of being tossed in the trash, and they take volumetric physical space. While they're not photoshoppable and do represent concrete fixed moments in time, you're the only one that can appreciate them. By putting them into "the cloud" (aka "other people's computers"), they stand less of a chance of being lost in time and they have a wider audience to appreciate them (especially for historians). BTW, have you tried to buy a new slide projector lately? I'm not sure if anyone is even still making them (yes, you can find them on eBay, garage sales, etc, but I did say "new").

I struggle with this myself. It's easy to flip through a book of photographs, but much harder to mount that maybe still working 2TB Barracuda SCSI disk that hasn't been migrated on to more current media. And digital media is, of course, subject to its own set of problems.

I have a rather large collection of Nixie tubes. I keep telling myself one day I'll do something with them. Maybe I will and maybe I won't, but they're sitting down in the basement, taking up space. I have to make sure they don't get damaged. They don't represent a significant investment but at this point they're worth quite a bit more than I paid for them. And as long as they're sitting down there waiting for me, they own me.

Notre Dame - as most of the gothic cathedrals - was modified all the time throughout the centuries. Most of the stuff you see now on Notre Dame is fake, romanticised gothic from the 19th century. Whenever the new architectural need rose - the building was adapted. It is not standing there just to be there - it was erected to serve the people and continues to evolve to better suit the needs.

As for the notre dame argument, there's also an architectural argument going on. Architects on the whole have a problem with outright copying others. So, if a building burns down, and it's rebuilt, is it a restoration or are you building a copy? Now apply that to a 900 year old historic cathedral. You can never get back those 900 year old timbers or copper roofing or the paintings or the spire. Anything you put back is a copy, a recreation. So, is it right to put a copy back in the originals place? Or is it right to put an interpretation of the original back? Would you want a photocopy of the original or would you want to recreate the feeling of the original in something new? That's why you see a lot of proposals out there for changes to the cathedral
